text:
Changed recipe for simplicity: 2 1/2 Cup Aunt Jemima Original Pancake Mix, 3 TBS brown sugar, 2 1/2 tsp pumpkin pie spice, 1 egg, 1 3/4 cup milk, 2 TBS vegetable oil, 2 TBS vinegar, 1 cup pumpkin puree. These were fantastic!

text:
I love this recipe; it's a hearty, stick-to-your-ribs breakfast. The following are a couple tips for the best pancakes. Don't thin the batter with more milk. This washes out the pumpkin flavor. Instead, the batter should be portioned out with a 1/4 c. measure onto a moderately hot griddle; then the batter should be spread out slightly using a spoon or a small spatula. This creates the fluffy texture while keeping them hearty. Second, I used a food processor to mix up the wet ingredients. This makes a smoother batter as it breaks down the fiberous pumpkin. The result is a lighter pancake with a more pronounced pumpkin flavor. Third, I used a fresh, good quality pumpkin pie spice rather than measuring out the individual spices; this is an easier preparation, and the flavors were fresher  (I get my pumpkin pie spice from a local spice shop that grinds and mixes it weekly for the best quality). Fourth, I got the best results either using whole milk or evaporated milk. Low-fat and fat free milk products just left the flavor dull.

text:
With a little tweeking, this recipe is fantastic.  I've been modifying this recipe for quite some time to perfect it.  I thought the pumpkin taste was too weak originally, and it lacked a true "pumpkin recipe flavor" without nutmeg.  Also, the cinnamon flavor was not noticeable.  Here are my suggestions:

1.  Add 1 1/3 cups pumpkin
2.  Add 1 Tbsp Cinnamon
3.  Add 1/2 tsp nutmeg
4.  Delete the allspice, vinegar and ginger

Here are my ingredients:
2 cups all-purpose flour
3 tablespoons brown sugar
2 teaspoons baking powder
1 teaspoon baking soda
1 tablespoon ground cinnamon
½ teaspoon nutmeg	1/2 teaspoon salt
1 1/2 cups milk
1 1/3 cups pumpkin puree
1 egg
2 tablespoons vegetable oil

It makes a nice dense pumpkiny flavor pancake that is fantastic with any decent syrup.  I've made it several times and get rave reviews always.

text:
As an old pancake/waffle baker I was eager to try this recipe.  I followed many suggestions in the reviews (2 eggs, 1 cup whole wheat PASTRY flour) and tweaked it even further.  My daughter had just eaten at a trendy breakfast cafe in Ashland, Oregon and claimed these were even better...lighter, etc.  Extra suggestions...add fresh nutmeg (1/2 t.), ground cloves (1 t.) increase cinnamon to 1 TABLESPOON and ground ginger to 2 teaspoons, brown sugar to 4 Tablespoons, ditto oil.  Also increase leavening to 2 TABLESPOONS ( I use only Rumford's and NO baking soda at all).  Finally, mix w. 1 plus cup of milk, let stand to absorb the dries and then add MORE milk to get that perfect pancake batter conistency.  Works well as waffles, also.

text:
These pancakes are OUT OF THIS WORLD! They're moist and delicious!
As always, I used REAL pumpkin instead of the canned stuff (I think it makes
a HUGE difference and real pumpkins are so easy to cook--I just cut them in 
half, scoop out the insides, and then put them face down on a baking sheet at
425 degrees for about an hour. After they cool, the skins come off very easily. 
Then take the pumpkin and mash it with a potato masher. Just make sure that
you use the right kind of pumpkins--sweet ones like New England or Baby Pam.
The big ones at the supermarket will not work).
Then I put butter REAL maple syrup on the pancakes, but they're so good, you 
could almost eat them plain! 5 stars!

text:
I used an electric skillet on 300 degrees...if you follow the recipe completely your pancakes will come out great.  Adding water or more milk takes away from the flavor.  Once you place the batter on the skillet, just spread it out a little with the back of a spoon...that will help thin the pancakes out.  Great recipe for picky eaters!!

text:
AWESOME!!!  I start by making the recipe just as it calls to be made so that when I rate a recipe those who read the review know what the recipe might be like from my perspective if you make it LIKE THE RECIPE SAYS!!!  I know this might be a novel idea but please give it a try!!!!  I did have to add additional liquid as it was a bit too thick.  When I see a recipe calling for milk and vinegar, these two mixed together give you an emergency substitute for buttermilk.  Next time I will go ahead a use buttermilk!!!   To the person who used the pancake mix - do not rate recipes like this if you are not going to follow the recipe as you did not make this recipe at all!

text:
INCREDIBLE! I like making my own pumpkin puree and this is a great way to use what's left over if the sugar (pie) pumpkin produces more than the 2 cups needed for pies and breads. I didn't have a whole cup of pumpkin so I just scaled the recipe down with great results. I added a bit of milk to the batter to make it easier to pour. TIP: The pancakes will be lighter if you let the batter sit 5 minutes or so before cooking -- that gives the baking powder time to react and start making air bubbles. Absolutely the best pumpkin pancakes ever!

text:
Excellent collection of spices in a slighty sweetened pancake. I needed to add about a 1/4 more of milk to get the pancakes thinner and I mixed the dry ingredients before the wet ones because I was worried the vinegar might curdle the milk. This is a keeper. I'll be doing some experimenting to add some whole grain texture to the recipe. Cooks magazine did a multi-grain pancake making a "flour" out of meusli.
I love IHOP pumpkin pancakes and these are just as good. The recipe is easy and the house smells good cooking them.

text:
I used whole wheat flour, Splenda brown sugar blend, 1 1/2 teaspoons homemade pumpkin pie spice, and lowfat buttermilk. I used my 1/4 measuring cup to measure out even pancakes so they turned out kind of small because they didn't spread much but they're light and fluffy. My family dug them. I like that they use only a touch of sugar so you really get the pumpkin flavor. This is a great pancake! NOTE: I think next time, I might add a 1/4 cup of chopped pecans.

text:
followed this recipe, except for slightly upping the cinnamon and ginger, and added an extra tablespoon of brown sugar for personal preferences.  OUTSTANDING!  I portion it out with a large ice cream scooper- it made 15 pancakes.  Perfect with a bit of maple syrup, and my kids like to put chocolate chips on top instead.  I've tried a lot of pumpkin pancakes and they are either too heavy, mushy, or they don't have enough flavor.  These are light and fluffy with great texture and flavor... make them NOW!  :)

text:
What a great fall recipe!  These would make a great Turkey Day b-fast.  I made a few changes:  I don't like ginger and didn't have AllSpice, so I doubled the cinnamon and added a dash of Nutmeg (next time, I'll do just straight cin, no nutmeg).  I used Splenda brown sugar blend and whole wheat flour.  I also added an extra slash of milk because the batter looked really really thick.  I used canned pumpkin.  I thought these had a delightfully nice slightly stronger than subtle pumpkin flavor.  I served w/"Cinnamon Cream Syrup" from here (per prior reviews) and it was a pancake/syrup match made in heaven.  Thanks for a great recipe.

text:
My family loves this recipe!  I substitute 1 C quick cooking oats & 1 C cream of wheat for the flour.  Also, 1/4 C eggbeaters in place of the egg and 2 T applesauce in place of the oil to make this recipe weight watcher (core plan) friendly.  I usually double the recipe and keep it refrigerated so that we can have pancakes on school days without going through too much hassle in the morning! Yummy!

Amazing, love the texture of the batter, and of course the pancake! Used evaporated milk for the milk, 2 1/2 tsp. pumpkin pie spice to replace all of the separate spices, and then added about a tsp. of vanilla. Oh and, not that it needs it, but I used half cake flour and half all purpose flour just because I'm trying to get rid of the cake flour. I'm sure it would be just as amazing using 100% all-purpose flour. Fabulous recipe!

text:
These pancakes were awesome!! Only change I made was to substitute whole wheat flour for the all-purpose flour, and add a dash more milk. The key for me was to measure out the 1/4 cup servings, pour them into the hot skillet, and then use the side of the measuring cup to gently spread the batter out. Then, after they cooked a bit on one side, I flipped them over and gently pressed on them with the back of a spatula to flatten them a bit more and ensure that they cooked through. They came out terrific and I topped them with a bit of sugar-free syrup, butter spread, and chopped pecans. Yummy!!

text:
I made this pancake recipe exactly as it was posted and I was NOT impressed. The batter was way too thick. It wouldn't spread out evenly (even with an offset spatula as was recommended in other reviews) so they cooked unevenly. I made half as is and then thinned out the batter with a bit more milk for the second half. While the second batch cooked better I found both batches to be spongey, like chewing a kitchen sponge, and while it tasted like pumpkin it could have used a touch more sugar as the bites I had that were light on syrup were bland.   I am a very experienced cook having been a sous chef in a restaurant and I know how to cook pancakes. I'll try this recipe again with some major adjustments but the original recipe is mediocre at best.

text:
I made these 10/20/2007.  Very yummy, everyone loved these.  Watch them closely on the griddle because they do burn easily.  I used 1 cup of pastry wheat flour in place of 1 cup of the white flour and I replaced 3 T of the white flour with milled flax seed.  I also made the hot cider syrup recipe from another pumpkin pancake recipe on this site and that was super simple and went well with these.  I also used the remaining pumpkin from the 15 oz. can I used and mixed it with 1 to 1-1/2 cup of vanilla yogurt and 1/4 tsp. of pumpkin pie spice for a pumpkin yogurt to dollop of top of these.

text:
Very tasty pancakes! I used fresh buttermilk in place of both the milk and vinegar. Also I had a little more than 2/3 cups of pumpkin (1 cup) and I added that into the mix. I added about 1 teaspoon of white sugar to the batter. The batter came together nice and thick. I scooped ¼ cup of batter onto the griddle and they puffed up nicely while cooking on the grill. The aroma of pumpkin quickly filled up my house while the pancakes cooked. I made 11 medium size pancakes which was more than enough for the next two days. It was a filling, hearty and tasty breakfast. The pancake itself was fluffy and moist and I could taste a hint of pumpkin. This is a nice blend of spices in a “slightly sweet” pancake. My family said that the pancakes tasted like “pumpkin pie.” Next time I may add ½ tsp. of pumpkin spice to the mix. This is a nice change to plain pancakes especially for fall season.

text:
This was a really good recipe.  I followed the recipe almost exact, the only thing I modified was the flour.  Instead of 2 cups white flour, I used 1 cup white flour, 1/2 cup whole wheat, 1/4 cup minute oats, 1/4 cup wheat bran, and about a tbsp of ground flax seeds.  It makes for a really thick batter, but I just made sure to spread it out on the griddle instead of thinning it out with extra milk.  The only thing I wasn't too sure about was the ginger, as you can feel the heat from it.  I haven't decided whether I like that aspect yet or not.  I may just decrease the amount I use in the future, but overall, this was a really tasty recipe.  Thank you! :)

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674152.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a hearty savory pumpkin pancake recipe. It's not too sweet, and the pumpkin flavor comes through. I put in more cinnamon, but that's a personal preference. A few drops of vanilla and little fresh grated nutmeg added some depth. I did not use allspice as I don't like it, and used half the ginger specified as I don't like a strong ginger flavor.  Hints: Don't overmix! Use a large spoon or spatula to fold the dry and wet together til they are JUST mixed. I took the suggestion of dissolving the brown sugar in with the other liquid ingredients.  Let the batter sit for ~15 minutes before cooking, the vinegar/baking soda/powder need to start working.  The batter IS thick, just spread out on the griddle with a spoon. I only used medium heat, anything higher would have burned my pancakes before they were cooked through.  This is a keeper recipe :)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were pretty tastey as is. I made a batch according to the recipe as written, and my husband and I both agreed that they were a bit on the dry side. Also the spices were lovely, but larger measurements are needed. I tried this recipe again, only this time I used 1&1/2 cups of pumpkin, doubled the cinnamon and ginger, and bumped up the brown sugar to 1/3 cup. Much tastier! This would bring this recipe up to 5 stars in our opinion. One tip, too, if you are using brown sugar, whisk it into your wet ingredients to dissolve it. Mixing it into the dry results in lumps, and if you try to mix them out once the wet and dry are incorporated, you will way over mix the batter. I agree w/ another reviewer, don't add anymore liquid to this recipe. Just spread the batter about with the back of the ladle, or whatever you are using. Adding more milk will dilute the pumpkin and spice flavor. Thanks for sharing this recipe!

These were wonderful - no changes in the ingredients necessary. In the method I took a shortcut by putting all ingredients except for the flour and baking powder into a food processor and blitzed it for 30 seconds. Then I added the flour and baking powder and blitzed for about 20 sec's. - Now they were ready to fry. Quick easy and very tasty! My family loved it. Thanks for posting.

These pancakes are wonderful!  I like to try a recipe as printed first.  This time I doubled the recipe to use the full can of pumpkin...and unlike some recipes this made a HUGE amount.  The really cool thing is that the left-overs keep wonderfully.  Toss them into the toaster on a darker setting, and they are as good as the first time around.  My 2YO says "I love pumpkin pancakes, Daddy!"  and anything that gets a stamp of approval from a 2YO, well that says something.  I'm anxious to try this again with some of the mods...but over all fantastic recipe, will definitely make again. text:
I've made these twice: Once with the recipe as written and once with a couple adjustments. They turned out delicious both times. I love them and will make them again and again. For the adjustments, I added two tablespoons of molasses to the wet ingredients and I increased the cinnamon in the dry ingredients. The result was a slightly sweeter, spicier pancake. Some people have said they couldn't get the pancakes to set. Spreading them with the back of a spoon to thin them out helped. Plus, these pancakes are very moist and cake-like, so they tend to be less dry in the middle than a traditional pancake.

text:
Made them as written, except for two things. I used whole wheat flour and I doubled everything so we could have leftovers in the freezer. I used pumpkin puree I made myself. 

The pumpkin flavor is mild, but it goes very well with maple syrup. Next time I might go heavier on the spices, as they were quite mild also and I like them punchy. 

Next time I might also put the brown sugar in with the wet ingredients, as it's a pain to chase the lumps out with a fork when it's in the dry stuff. 

The batter is a 'dry' batter, not runny like a lot of people are used to. This is rather like a muffin batter, and spreading it around with the disher is an excellent technique. I make my pancakes very small--silver dollar style--so they will be easier to handle on my griddle.

text:
I took the advice of many of the women and pureed the pumpkin in a food processor for a better consistency. Instead of 1 cup, I used 1.5 cups of pumpkin puree. My husband and I also like the pancakes with more flavor so we increased the allspice and cinnamon from 1 teaspoon to 1.5 teaspoons. I added 1 teaspoon of pumpkin spice and added 1 teaspoon of vanilla extract. We thought the original recipe was good but not enough flavor. Use a spoon to thin out the mixture once on the griddle, don't add more milk or eggs as it will take away from the flavor. We made this for my husband's office last year and it was such a big hit we actually ran out. I have made it several times at home and will be making it again for his office next week. This is a wonderful recipe.

I am bit unusual since I made these on a hot May morning in Texas instead of a cool fall day. But I think that are great anytime of the year.  Very light and flavorful.  The only changes I made were to use two eggs instead of one and I added some vanilla extract.  And don't be afraid to add the vinegar to the milk. text:
WOW!!! Nicely spiced vehicles for your maple syrup. This recipe works equally well with cooked, pureed sweet potato. I nuke them for 4 minutes, scoop out the flesh and mash it well before incorporating. Also, I use buttermilk in place of the milk and vinegar. I find that I end up using the same measure of buttermilk as of flour, otherwise the batter is too thick and the pancakes won't cook well in the centers. It's easy to tinker with the spices to suit your taste. I like to add a dash of cloves as well as those in the recipe, plus I double the cinnamon and ginger. These puff up nicely and come out tender and oh-so-tasty!

These pancakes are fantastic!! I have 3 fussy girls and 2 will eat-anything-in-sight boys and everyone loves these pumpkin pancakes. I have to double the recipe to make sure everyone gets enough. The only thing I do differently is omit the allspice, increase the cinnamon to 1 1/2 teaspoons and I add a 1/2 teaspoon of nutmeg. This is a keeper for sure!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I usually try to find something redeeming about any recipe or try to fix it in a way I'll enjoy but after 2 batches done in 2 different ways, they will never make it into my recipe box.

First off my biggest annoyance was the fact they did NOT cook in the middle and they would not flip for anything. The batter gunked up 2 spatulas and I kept having to rinse them off just to try and turn the pancakes. It was completely a waste of time trying.

Second, the vinegar the first time? Why? It made them taste so acidicy and there was nothing I could do to save the flavor. I added extra sugar, more flour, vanilla and nothing worked. The 2nd time I didn't use vinegar and it still tasted sour, just not as...bubbly. 

Although the pumpkin in the batter is what is making the pancakes doughy in the middle, it could be fixed but I don't have the patience or the ingredients to waste on this recipe. It was a total flunk in my book. I won't ever use this recipe again.

These are wonderful! I doubled the recipe right off the bat so that I could stock the freezer, and it made about 40 pancakes using a 1/4 cup scoop. Also, to make it healthier, I used skim milk, applesauce in place of the oil, and used 1/2 whole wheat flour and 1/2 all purpose. Oh, and since it didn't specify the type of vinegar I used apple cider vinegar. Delicious! Thank you for sharing!

This is a great recipe, made it for overnight guests. I didn't have allspice, so doubled the cinnamon. Thinned it out with milk too. For a great syrup that compliments this better than maple... text:
Mmmmm. We liked these.  Hubby thought they tasted healther than the other pancakes I've been making.  I made them for hubby and myself on a rainy morning and it was very hearty and delicious.  Used 1/4 cup whole wheat and the rest white flour.  Added 1 tsp pumpkin spice in addition to the spices called for. Also added 1 tsp vanilla per hubby's request.  Used most of the can of pumpkin puree and used the rest as topping like applesauce.  (Mixed with butter and cinnamon). Poured butter and maple syrup on the pancakes -- we each had three pancakes and I froze the rest -- delicious and a nice change!

These are the best pumpkin pancakes I've ever had!  Fluffy and light, and not too much spice.  I make them silver dollar-sized, and after breakfast we snack on them all day- they really don't even need syrup.  I made a few tiny adjustments-
add the vinegar to the milk and set aside for a minute to sour 
left out the allspice (don't like it)
increased the cinnamon and brown sugar a touch

text:
These turned out yummy with a little tweaking. I didn't think they were quite sweet enough so I added another tablespoon of brown sugar. I did add just a little nutmeg, but I love nutmeg. I also thought that this was very thick as is, and wasn't a good pancake batter. It wouldn't spread. So, I added maybe 1/4 cup milk. I don't think it hurt the flavor at all and made it much easier to work with. They were so light and soft and fluffy, and perfect with butter and syrup served with a side of bacon. The only thin I would have done differently is, I would have liked a little vanilla in it, but I seem to have misplaced mine.

text:
Incredible! The pumpkin flavor is just right (not too strong, not too mild). But to make this even easier, I just used the canned pumpkin PIE puree. It already has all these seasonings in it. I didn't need to add anything extra except for the brown sugar and salt (in other words, I was able to omit the allspice, cinnamon, and ginger). And I think I was careful about the sugar, because the pumpkin pie puree is sweeter than just the plain pumpkin puree. Your choice. Whatever you do, these are awesome and totally appropriate for the season, but yummy any time of year!

These were deeeeelicious!  I followed the recipe pretty closely, with the exception of subbing in buttermilk for the regular milk and then only adding one Tbsp. of apple cider vinegar.  I kept the spices the same as well as the pumpkin.  These pancakes were super fluffy and moist!  And the pumpkin flavor really isn't that strong. So for anyone worried that the pumpkin is overpowering, don't be!  All I had on hand was pancake syrup, but I think some real maple syrup or even some spice up whipped cream, and maybe a handful of toasted pecans, would be just perfect.  Thank you for sharing this recipe with us.  :-)

Display Name:
BETTYTAMS

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a good base to start off of, but the recipe as is needed tweaking for my tastes.  I used a whole wheat baking mix so I left out the baking soda and baking powder.  I just used 2 cups of the mix.  I hate allspice so I deleted that too.  I ended up using a whole can of pumpkin, but I really like pumpkin.  I doubled the cinnamon and the ginger.  I also added more brown sugar, about 1/4 cup.  I also used skim milk and cut the oil to 1 Tbsn.  I kind of just tasted the recipe until it was how I liked it.  As far as the vinegar, use cider vinegar.  I have made these 3x and used no vinegar first, used white the second, and cider the 3rd.  The vinegar makes them fluffier I think, but white vinegar I could taste.  I used a lot of pumpkin so mine were very moist!!  I loved it though because I love the pumpkin pie flavor.  Also, the batter was a bit thick at the end so I added water.  My advice, taste the batter because if you do not like it in the bowl, you won't like it when it is done.  You can adjust from there.

Beautiful and delicious...

text:
Ever since I had these at IHOP a couple of weeks ago I have been craving them.  Well I found this recipe and it is just like the ones that I had a couple of weeks ago.  I used a 1oz scoop to make my pancakes and I flattened them out a little bit, as someone else suggested.  I also cooked them until the tops were no longer shinny in appearance.  And then flipped them over.  I also used 1.5 tsp of pumpkin spice.  I also triple sifted the dry ingredients, because some said that they were quite dense.  My 5 year old and 2.5 year old LOVED them!!!  I also made some cinnamon butter and spread that on top.  These will be made again and again!!!

I've been looking for a recipe like this ever since I lost the one I had been using. The only thing I did differently is I used pumpkin pie spice instead of ginger. Everything else I did exactly as the recipe is printed. I found when I cooked these after I flipped them I had to press down on them to flatten them out or else they didn't cook in the middle. They were so thick. As long as I did that they cooked to perfection. I use my food processor to mix everything and poured the batter into a pitcher for pouring onto the skillet. I had a yield of 15 medium size pancakes. My family has no interest in eating plain pancakes after eating pumpkin pancakes. I would love to try this for waffles.

The first time I made these I followed the recipe exactly and was bitterly disappointed.  The second time I followed another reviewers recipe and used these ingredients and it was fantastic. Delete the allspice, vinegar and ginger Here are my ingredients: 2 cups all-purpose flour 3 tablespoons brown sugar 2 teaspoons baking powder 1 teaspoon baking soda 1 tablespoon ground cinnamon ½ teaspoon nutmeg	1/2 teaspoon salt 1 1/2 cups milk 1 1/3 cups pumpkin puree 1 egg 2 tablespoons vegetable oil."

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed this recipe EXACTLY.
These had a nice flavor but were too dry and dense. I'm sure there's things you could do to make it fluffier like using pastry flour or extra eggs but I feel that if you don't follow the recipe exactly you can't give it a fair star rating so I always follow it exactly the first time. 
Next time I'll definitely add an extra egg, more milk and probably some blueberries or chocolate chips to make it fluffier and more moist.
EDIT; made them a second time with a few changes to make them HEALTHIER :)
sub 4 egg whites for eggs, sub 2 Tablespoons applesauce for oil, sub 1 cup protein powder for 1 cup of flour (depending on your brand of protein powder you may not be able to do this or you may need to add extra baking powder to make them fluffy), completely omitted brown sugar, sub 3 teaspoons pumpkin pie spice for spices and added about 1 cup blueberries. Added a few Tablespoons extra milk until the batter seemed to pour a little nicer. 
I found with these changes the recipe was a much better consistency. Pancakes were moist, taisty and liked by all. (Plus MUCH less fattening and fewer carbs)

text:
Yum, yum! These were the BOMB!!! My husband isn't home for dinner on Tuesdays. He HATES pumpkin ANYTHING and I am IN LOVE with the stuff (ha!), so I use this night to make my favorite seasonal dishes. :) Not only were these EASY to make, they were SUPER delicious and even easier to eat lol! Because this recipe makes a significantly large batch of pancakes, I invited my neighbor over to help polish them off.... Other than adding ~ 1/2 c. of semi-sweet chocolate chips to my batter, using vanilla baking oil instead of regular vegetable oil (I had it, so why not???) and subbing pumpkin pie spice for the individual spices called for (I didn't have any allspice, hence the substitution), I made no "real" changes. This recipe needs no tweaks or enhancements - it's perfect as is! Maple syrup and a pat of whipped butter sprinkled with cinnamon were nice touches. Breakfast sausage links and steaming mugs of apple cider rounded out our meal. Thanks SO much for sharing your AWESOME recipe, Ruth! I now have a new seasonal favorite to add to my growing collection and my neighbor wants the recipe so she can make these herself! :-)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this a couple times. As is, it's just "okay." The batter is VERY thick. I tried both low and high heats on my griddle and neither seemed to cook them through. It seems like 1/2-3/4 cup more milk makes the batter more workable, but it does "wash out" the flavor (as some others have mentioned). I've found that adding an extra 1/2 cup of pumpkin puree, doubling the spices (including salt), and adding 1/2-3/4 cup more milk is a good compromise. My family loves these pancakes!

text:
Great recipe.  Love how they have just a hint of sweetness.  I doubled the recipe, then added an additional egg.  (Doubling the recipe uses up a whole can of pumpkin.) Used 1/2 whole wheat pastry flour, 1/2 all-purpose flour.  I was heavy handed on the cinnamon because we like it.  Added vanilla also.  When I put the batter down on the pan, I sprinkled crushed walnuts for those of us that like them.  Used up leftover batter by pouring into a muffin pan, then sprinkling crushed walnuts on top.  Haven't tasted them yet, but they look beautiful.  Thanks for the recipe.  :D

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used to hate pumpkin growing up and now I devour anything remotely pumpkin flavored. I made this for my boyfriend and I for breakfast as a pre-Halloween treat. 

I followed the recipe according to instructions except altered somewhat according to the other reviews: I added an extra egg, a 1/4 cup more of pumpkin, an additional tablespoon of brown sugar (my boyfriend has an insane sweet tooth), and used 2 tsps of Pumpkin Pie spice versus the individual spices. I also found the batter to be a bit thick so I added some water. 

I also found that the pancakes need more time to cook on each side than normal pancakes (the batter is a bit thicker due to the pumpkin). 

The flavor was clearly pumpkin but not overly sweet. Almost like a pumpkin muffin in flavor. My boyfriend loved it (he ate 8 at once!) so it is a hit. Easy to make and beautiful end result color/texture.

text:
I don't know what I did wrong. I followed the recipe and instructions to the T and the batter came out really thick. I know I am not supposed to taste it because of the raw egg, but I did anyways and the batter tasted really dull. I don't like to give up after the first try, so I will make these again, maybe tonight or tomorrow morning. I will read some reviews and take some suggestions from the others and we'll see if that works out a little better.
**UPDATE: As promised, I made these again but with modifications, added 1 tsp vanilla extract, added the dry ingredients to the wet by adding 1/2 cup of the flour first, then 1 tablespoon at a time till I got to the right consistency, I also used lemon juice instead of the vinegar. When finished I used a 1/4 measuring cup to pour the batter onto the pan, spread the batter softly with a spatula and flipped once the big bubbles started to appear. These were much much better this way. Thank you for sharing =)

Changed recipe for simplicity: 2 Cups Bisquick Pancake Mix, 3 TBS brown sugar, 1 egg, 1 1/2 cup milk, 2 TBS vinegar, 1 teaspoon allspice, 1 teaspoon ground cinnamon, 1/2 teaspoon ground ginger, and 1 can of pumpkin puree (not the giant!).

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Although my family and I enjoyed these hearty pancakes, they need lots of tweaking to make them memorable.  The batter is very thick, so I used an ice cream scoop to get them on the griddles. I followed the suggestions of quickly spreading out the batter as it was placed on the griddle. I lowered the heat so they wouldn't burn before the center was cooked and they came out perfectly. Even though we all prefer thin pancakes, the texture and heartiness of these was perfect for a cold morning. On to the flavor...pretty bland. It seemed like there was plenty of spices added to the batter but after making one pancake as a test, I found it lacking in flavor. I had to go back and add another round of the spices, plus some nutmeg. I also added a teaspoon of vanilla. I felt it was too late to add more pumpkin without ruining the batter but next time I will. The pumpkin flavor is almost non-existent. So, all in all, this recipe is a good starting point and I will make it again but with some changes.

text:
This is a great fall breakfast.  I made a couple small tweaks to suit our taste, extra spices and pumpkin.  I'll definitely be making these again. I might make the batter ahead of time to let the flavors develop more. Pumpkin pie is always better the next day so perhaps the same is true for these.  I don't understand the negative comments about a lack of flavor.  These had a nice fall flavor and pancakes are not typically loaded with flavor.  These are worth trying and make sure to use real maple syrup!  Thanks Ruth.

text:
Absolutely fabulous!  The way I know I have a winner is when my kids whine at me:  "Mooommyyyy, I want another paaaancaaaake!"  Both of them did.  We loved them!  The only changes I made were to omit the allspice, which I didn't have, so I subbed nutmeg; added about 1/4 cup more pumpkin, because I wanted a big pumpkin flavor; and then added about 1/3 cup more milk to thin out the batter.  Delicious!  I took another reviewer's suggestion of using a spoon to spread the batter a little in the pan after pouring, which worked out fantastically.

Today was the 3rd time I made these. I double every thing and freeze 1/2 of them when done. I used whole wheat flour today and they came out fine. The grandkids loved them and they are better for me. Followed recipe exactly. The batter is very thick so when you put the 1/4 cup of batter on the griddle you need to use the back of a spoon to gently spread it out a little. 9/4/09 Made them today using 1/2 allpurpose flour and 1/2 whole wheat, added some pumpkin spice and flax seed. Love them. 8/28/10 Made them this morning, added some finely chopped pecans which made a good addition.

I thought the pancakes tasted kind of bland.  Try the suggestions of others for spicing up these pancakes if you are going to try them for the first time. The recipe was fine, even though the batter was a bit thick.  My husband and daughter thought the pancakes were good. I thought a sprinkling of turbinado sugar perked them up a bit, adding a bit of sweetness and some crunch to them.

text:
These were great to make and freeze, for a quick breakfast; however, I believe there is twice the amount of baking powder needed. These were so thick, even when I spread them out very thin, they rose and grew thicker. I didn't make the syrup and kids (10&8) loved them. They really do stick to your ribs, and I'll keep them in my file to make again, next time reducing the amount of baking powder. I hope halving the amount won't compromise the integrity of such a thick batter. Thanks for the post.

text:
These were great pancakes.  I did change the recipe a bit:  half whole wheat flour/half all-purpose flour.  Instead of using milk/vinegar, buttermilk was used - same difference.  Because the batter was so thick, they were cooked at about 25 degrees cooler than suggested.   Next time we will add toasted pecans or walnuts.  We love the added crunch.  

The biggest change of all was that butternut squash was substituted for the pumpkin.  We have an abundance of butternut squash from our garden and frequently use it in lieu of pumpkin.  You really can't taste the difference.

text:
Yum, these are really good. Unsurprisingly they are reminiscent of pumpkin pie (without as much guilt!) - fantastic with butter and maple syrup, a little butter seems to really bring out the flavour. I had some leftovers and they were still great 1-2 days later, reheated in the microwave. Next time I'll try upping the spices a little, as suggested by previous reviewers, but still a 5 star recipe.

Display Name:
Kimberly Patton Borgeson
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2003405.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the ULTIMATE in nummy pancakey goodness!  :-)
  I serve these whenever we have guests and EVERYONE LOVES THEM!  I do it a little differently than the recipe, never the same twice.  I use a mix of whole wheat, oat, and (a little) white flour.  I add at least a 1/2 cup of flax meal as well.  I use more pumpkin and always use two eggs instead of one.  I adjust the thickness by adding extra milk as needed to get just the right consistency.  Oh, I also use 1tsp of pumpkin pie spice on top of all the other spices.  With the flour mix it needs a little extra spice.  They take a bit longer to cook but are worth it.  These are healthy and delicious and I feel good about serving them to my family.  With the flax meal they get some additional Omegas in their diet. Try it...you'll love it!

text:
These pancakes are so good!  If you have thick pumpkin (Libby's, etc) make sure you add an extra cup of milk and one extra egg.  If you have soupy pumpkin, don't worry about it.  I added chocolate chips to some of my pancakes (I know that sounds weird, but don't knock it till you try it) and it was yummy.  Thanks for the the great pancakes!

text:
Amazing!! Made a few adjustments as to what I had on hand. Used 2 eggs instead of 1 and started with one cup of whole milk. I also used 2 cups of whole wheat pastry flour, 4 Tbsp of brown sugar, along with 3 tsp of pre mixed pumpkin pie spice plus 1 tsp of cinnamon. After the wet and dry was combined, added about another 1/4 cup of milk. Also whipped up some cinnamon and brow sugar butter and used real maple syrup!! So good!!

text:
I followed Nancy's (the highest ranking reviewer) recipe. I wanted to buy Trader Joe's pumpkin waffle mix but they didn't have it, so I was looking for a substitute, and oh my god, is this stuff great. Normally you need syrup for pancakes, but with these one you don't! They taste delicious by themselves! I keep eating them as I make them! 5+ stars! I used Krusteaz waffle mix instead of whatever else everybody's using, don't think it matters though! It's a fool-proof recipe!

country:
None
text:
Love these pancakes! They are pretty easy to make as well. I usually make them exactly as the recipe states except that I omit the allspice (because I never have any). I think they taste just fine without it. The batter will likely be thicker than you're used to, but trust me, they come out perfectly.  Make sure they are fully cooked through or they will be doughy and mushy.  I tend to flatten mine out with the spatula to aid with the process and to gauge how "mushy" they feel.  Whether that works?  Who knows? :) But you should definitely try these!  I have eaten them with homemade cinnamon syrup and apple cider syrup (both recipes from this site).  Lots of compliments from the people for whom I have made these.

text:
Not liking this.  The first thing I found wrong was the ratio of wet to dry ingredients.  I was so frustrated I watched a video on here on how to make pumpkin pancakes, which shouldn't be hard but I am not a breakfast cook.  The video states a CUP of pumpkin not an entire can, every other ingredient and measurement was the same.  When there are too many wet ingredients it tastes raw and undercooked.  Too many dry and it didn't cook right.  I did not like the spices, too little pumpkin flavor and too much allspice.  I will experiment with the ingredients and read through more reviews because the concept of pumpkin pancakes sounds yummy.

I made these with Almond milk and used my own pumpkin-spice, and they were lovely. :) I made a pumpkin syrup by heating together pumpkin butter, brown sugar, maple syrup, apple cider vinegar, butter, and a splash of lemon juice. I just finished eating these pumpkin puncakes, and they are fantastic!  I made the recipe as written with only one small change - I was short 1/4 c. of pumpkin puree, so I added applesauce to make up the difference (I couldn't detect the applesauce - I think it just added needed moisture).  As other reviewers have mentioned, these do need a little help to get them to spread out, so I used the back of the measuring cup I was pouring the batter into the skillet with.  So glad I finally tried this recipe :)

text:
I made these this morning and doubled the recipe so I could use 1 can of pumpkin (15 oz).  I followed the recipe excepting I used a pumpkin pie spice mix in place of the allspice, cinnamon and ginger and a wheat/white flour mix in place of all white flour.  They were a little thick (a little short on the pumpkin?) so I added about 1/3 cup more milk.  The pancakes were fluffy and delish.  I dipped them in just a little maple syrup.  Freeze the leftovers with a piece of wax paper between each pancake for easy toaster breakfasts during the week.

Wow!  Awesome pancakes!  The flavor and texture of these reminded me so much of pumpkin bread.  I did notice that many of my pancakes had gooey middles. I served these with another allrecipes recipe, absolute best pancake syrup, and they paired so well together!  It was the ultimate pancake breakfast.  So good!  Thanks for this great recipe!

text:
I've been on a pumpkin kick and was wondering what to do with my leftover puree from my last baking adventure. These pancakes were the perfect solution! I used a lil over 1.5 cups of buttercream instead of the milk+vinegar combo. The batter was a lil thick so I add a splash more of buttercream at the end. They baked up thick but fluffy. I topped with warm maple syrup, toasted pecans and nutmeg whipped cream. I wanted to make whipped cream from scratch but the pancakes came together so quickly that I just ended up sprinkling some nutmeg in Cool Whip...worked great. The flavors were the epitome of fall with just the right balance of spice and sweetness. I only cooked a half batch so I'm already looking forward to tomorrow to whip up the rest.  Thank you Ruth!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Just made these pancakes and they were EXCELLENT. Note:  I made the following changes-used Butter Milk (instead of reg. milk), used 2 teasp. of Pumpkin Pie Spice by MacCormick (instead of allspice, cinnamon & ginger).  Otherwise, I followed the recipe as written.  I combined all dry ingredients together, wisking for 2 min. until well combined.  Then I mixed wet ingredients in a separate bowl until well mixed.  I then added little by little the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients until well combined.  The batter for these pancakes were PERFECT!  I suggest you serve these with real maple syrup, as there is not other syrup that can compare to the real deal!  Make these, you will not be sorry!

text:
I followed this recipe to the T except even though I made half the recipe I added 2 Total Tablespoons of brown sugar, totaling an extra TB if it were the full recipe. The serving size is PERFECT, I was able to make 6 nicely sized pancakes with half of the recipe  These pancakes were great. Nice thick and fluffy. Cooked very easily. Try them with the syrup recipe on 'Pumpkin Waffles with Apple Cider Syrup' on this website.(see my review on that as well) YOU WILL NOT REGRET IT! Thanks to the submitter of this recipe for something different to start the Fall off with!

text:
I used whole wheat pastry flour, so I increased the baking soda and baking powder by 50%.  I also used 4 tbsp brown sugar.  Medium-high heat burned them or left raw middles, so I switched to medium heat and they came out great.  Using the 1/4 cup measurement, this made more like 18 pancakes, but everyone liked them enough to make them again, and it was a good use of extra pumpkin I had in the fridge.

I've made these several times now, and both my toddler son and hubby gobble them up!  Delicious as is - I don't change anything.  Not sure what the vinegar does, but don't leave it out; the recipe is perfect with it.  Don't forget to spread the batter around a bit with a spoon once you pour it into the pan, otherwise the pancakes will be too think.  I also ran out of ginger when I made these this morning, and I added nutmeg instead - still delicious!  Thanks, Ruth, for getting my boys to eat pumpkin!

These were awesome!  I had a "long island cheese" pumpkin which produced 6 c of mashed pumpkin, so I was looking for things to do with it.  This was a GREAT choice! I did NOT try this recipe, but I wanted to give you this quick tip.  Krusteaz Buttermilk pancakes ("just add water"), the water, a couple of tablespoons of canned pumpkin, a couple shakes of pumpkin pie spice, and some chopped/broken pecans.  Serve with warm maple syrup.  You can do the same thing with mashed bananas & pecans!

0boyz4us

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
What a nice seasonal treat!  With Maple Syrup... yummy!   RE the "soft in the middle" comments.  Just cook at a low temp(2.5 or 3 on an electric) vs.. a hot griddle.  They need longer to cook than a traditional pancake... probably due to the pumpkin.  Don't be afraid of the vinegar... you can't taste it at all and makes them fluffy (ever mixed soda and vinegar?).  Next time I think I would put the sugar in with the milk mix. b/c it's clumpy and hard to blend in without over beating.   Kids never suspected there was something healthy hidden inside!  I said they were "fall" pancakes!

text:
I made these for the husband and kids and they were a big hit.  At first, they were coming out kind of spongy, like some of the other reviewers said in their feedback.  I found that you really have to let them cook longer than normal pancakes.  When you see the bubbles (which is a good indication with normal pancakes that it's time to flip), you should wait another minute or two.  They really crisp up beautifully and the taste is phenomenal if they're cooked thoroughly.

text:
I love these, but I would have to say plain maple syrup doesn't do them justice. There's a really simple recipe on this web page for cinnamon syrup that makes the pumpkin flavor really pop :) Yum! I've been told that bay leaf, oddly enough, makes pumpkin taste more ''pumpkiny', so I'm trying to think of a way to try that out with this recipe. I've made it several times and plan to start playing with it a little to see how it comes out - but they're Phenomenal exactly as is too.  I'm going to try nutmeg and cloves while leaving out the allspice. I also want to try kefir (it's like a drinkable yogurt) in place of the milk and leave out the vinegar since the kefir has lots of lactic acid from the beneficial bacteria.

text:
I made these exactly as written.  It's a thickish batter, yes, but I prefer a thick puffy pancake to flat ones anyway.  And if you use the 1/4 cup as stated in the recipe and spread it a bit, they should get done in the middle.  They are not big pancakes.  Made this way I got 14 of them.  I'd say this is anywhere from 4 to 6 servings depending on how much you want.  (Only 4 compared to a restaurant serving.)  They are subtle and not over-sweet, so don't expect sweet.   (The description says "barely-sweetened"!)  I prefer them this way and put nothing but some butter on them.  I think syrup ruins pancakes.  So why the 4? - well, cause they were pretty good but nothing grand.  I generally like pumpkin stuff & have never had pumpkin pancakes so thought I'd give them a try.  Seems like a good way to sneak in some veggie - the kids shouldn't notice.  (Though it seems to defeat the purpose just pouring sugar all over them.)

country:
None
text:
This is my most popular go-to pancake and waffle recipe. Turns out great every time. I occasionally will add more cinnamon and a dash of ground cloves. To send this over the top, I blend softened Smart Balance, honey, and cinnamon to top these with. Rarely do I even want to add pure maple syrup, but it still tastes wonderful with the extra sweetness. I have to say, though, that using fake syrups (as I call them) just make this too sickeningly sweet and take away from the wholesome ingredients. Plus, the store-bought pancake syrups are all HFCS (high fructose corn syrup) and can never taste as good as pure honey or pure maple syrup, which you'll use less of anyway because they're stronger in flavor for less product. Just my opinion though! Anyway, try these!

I used this recipe to get an idea on how much pumpkin and spices to add to my regular pancake recipe and with a few adjustments it really turned out great. text:
I made a batch of these this morning and the whole family liked them. They were so thick and puffy! I made a few health modifications by replacing the brown sugar with Splenda Brown Sugar Blend. I also used two egg whites rather than one whole egg. I used half whole wheat flour and half all-purpose flour. Finally, I cut the oil to 1 tablespoon and used a tablespooon of unsweetened applesauce as well. I measured the batter by 1/4 cup as stated and this recipe made 16 pancakes. I love pumpkin, so if I were to make these to my tastes, I'd add more pumpkin puree, but the less-pumpkin-loving members of the family thought they were just right.

These were good. I followed the directions, but still tweaked it. AMAZING!!  I made these just as is and they were perfect.  I served them with the Cinnamon Creme Syrup found on this site and it was a match made in heaven.  One suggestion: don't pour the syrup on the pancakes directly.  Dip them in the syrup just before eating.  The pancakes soak up the syrup so fast you don't taste it as much when you pour it on.

text:
Delicious!   After making a couple of batches of these wonderful pancakes I added a little more oil, about a tsp., a little more salt and I used pumpkin pie spice, 1 tbsp.  Also, I used 1 c. of silk nogg, or egg nog is fine too, and 1/2 c. 1 % milk.  This gave it a wonderful subtle flavor.
The pancakes are wonderful ~ not mushy in the middle like most pumpkin pancakes I've had...very delicious, my fave pancake recipe!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading other reviews, I altered mine a bit. I doubled the recipe for my big family, but instead of doubling the pumpkin to 2 cups, I used 1.5 cups. The batter was therefore less heavy and had a nice texture. I also turned down the heat by 50 degrees and edged it up so I could control cooking speed. I also adjusted seasonings to my taste--just cinnamon and nutmeg, as we prefer. And as I usually do with pancakes, I used half all-purpose flour and half soft whole wheat flour. I make my own maple syrup with maple flavor extract and threw in a little cinnamon. Five stars for this filling, tasty treat!
Review:
Rating:

userID:
1241884
Display Name:
Duckball
isPro:

409
favoritesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/678436.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So yummy! I made homemade pumpkin puree with a cooking pumpkin (Baby Bear) by washing the outside, cutting it in half vertically, scooping out the stringy insides (you can roast the seeds if desired!), put it in a microwave-safe dish with an inch or two of water, cover, microwave on high for 15-25 minutes until tender, scoop the flesh out of the skin, and puree with an emersion blender/regular blender/hand mixer. I cut the cinnamon down by about half (both my daughter and husband are allergic) and I let the batter sit for five or ten minutes before cooking the pancakes. The leftover pancakes were cooled and frozen - pop them in the microwave or toaster for a quick and delicious breakfast! Thanks for sharing, Ruth!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I love this pancake recipe! I've made it twice. Once with canned and the other with fresh pumpkin. Both were excellent. This has a lighter, moister texture than the typical pancake, so don't be fooled by the thick batter. I made a few adjustments as recommend. Added 1 1/3 cup pumpkin, 1 tbsp cinnamon and 1/2 tsp of nutmeg as well. I keep the vingar since it aides the rise, and I've also subbed buttermilk for milk before (no milk on hand that morning). Didn't add vingar when using buttermilk and the results were still the same. Also used 5 tbsp of brown sugar and folded in the dry to the wet. Folding is key to achieve a light, fluffy pancake.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/188845.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are my changes: 
1-1/2 cups milk, 1-1/3 cups pumpkin puree, 2 eggs, 2 T. veg oil, 2 cups flour, 3 T brown sugar, 2 tsp. baking powder, 1 tsp. baking soda, 2 tsp. cinnamon, 1/2 tsp. nutmeg, pinch of cloves, 1/2 tsp. salt,  1/2 tsp. pumpkin spice.  I actually put all the wet ingredients in a bowl and whisked them, then did the same with all the dry ingredients...then folded them together and gently whisked them with a metal whisk.  Make sure you leave them on the griddle long enough to cook  through since they are thicker.  KILLER PANCAKES!!!  Super pumpkin flavor.

text:
Delicious!  I was looking for a sweet potato pancake recipe but didn't want the work of cooking/peeling the potatoes (and had a can of pumpkin in the pantry).  Looked at the modifications in a few reviews and modified a bit:  added an extra egg, used a whole can of pumpkin (about 1 3/4 cups), added nutmeg and some pumpkin pie spice (instead of individual amounts of allspice & ginger), extra cinnamon, used coconut oil instead of vegetable oil and left out the vinegar.  These are thick, so they take a while to cook, but SOOOO worth it!  Moist and yummy.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe needs a lot of tweaking to come out right.  My first attempt I followed the recipe exactly...it was way too thick, and fairly flavorless.  (no idea how people are giving it four stars!)

The second batch I added the entire can of pumpkin.  It was still too thick, and I had to add an extra cup of water/milk mixture to thin it out to appropriate pancake consistency.  Even then, it never cooks right.  The middle stays pretty mooshy (likely due to the abundance of pumpkin puree, which unfortunately is the only thing giving it flavor).  I can tolerate the mooshy middle, but if you like to make pancakes and store for the week...I can't imagine these would hold up well.  

I'm not making a third attempt.  I'll just find a difference recipe.

text:
Had to make minor modifications, mostly because of what I had on hand. Subbed 1/2c of Soy Flour because I ran short on regular flour. I also used 2-1/2tsp Pumpkin Spice for the combo of cinnamon, allspice and ginger. Also used Almond Milk (unsweetened, vanilla). However even with these super minor changes, I don't think they affected the integrity of the recipe and hubs was super happy with it! This made a total of 22 pancakes (used 1/4c scoop to get even pancakes). Consistency was very silky, and they puffed up nicely. Very hearty, which was perfect. I did add a small handful of chopped walnuts to mine, although I didn't think it added anything. Just nice to have the crunch. We'll definitely make these again and will experiment with adding different things (granola, different nuts in the batter, dried cranberries, the possibilities are endless!). Thanks!!

I follow a reviewers tweaks and make them as follows:
2 C flour
3 T brown sugar
2 t baking powder
1 t baking soda
1 T cinnamon
1/2 t nutmeg
1/2 t salt
1 1/2 C milk
1 egg
2 T oil
1 1/3 C pumpkin

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first time making home made pancakes without a box mix. WOW. These are absolutely delicious!!! They are light, fluffy,  and hearty all at once!!! I made some changes since I didn't have all the ingredients. I didn't have milk so I used 1 cup buttermilk and half a cup of evaporated milk. I only used 1 Tbsp vinegar since I used buttermilk. I also added an additional tbsp of brown sugar, 1 tbsp white sugar, nutmeg, clove and pumpkin pie spice. These seriously taste like the consistency of IHOP pancakes which are my favorite!!! I was going to attempt a cream cheese glaze but decided to stick with IHOP syrup (which can be found at Walmart..you're welcome)

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6923757.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are fantastic! The changes I made were 1 1/2c. of pumpkin, didn't use allspice, added heaping tsp. cinnamon, 1/2tsp. ginger, 1/2tsp. nutmeg, 1/4tsp. cloves. I combined the milk and vinegar and let sit while I whisked the egg, pumpkin, and oil (coconut) together, then slowly added the milk. Then I combined all the dry ingredients, in a separate bowl, by whisking also. Then carefully mix wet and dry using a folding method, ONLY till mixed. Do not add extra milk! The batter is thick, but scoops and pours just fine, and cooks up very light and fluffy. We all loved them!

None
text:
I made it exactly as written and my pancakes came out bland and mushy. They never cooked through to a normal pancake texture no matter how long or how low heat I cooked them on; the inside stayed mushy and the outside burned. They tasted of raw pumpkin and the vinegar gave it a tang. Despite so many recipes claiming otherwise, vinegar + milk is NOT a substitute for buttermilk because the two just taste completely different and you can tell in the final product. This recipe is so, so flawed and I definitely will not make it again.

city:

text:
These are so good! Definitely a favorite! I usually use pumpkin or a bunch of smashed up bananas. Both are awesome. I keep the spices the same. I always run out of allspice so have used cinnamon and nutmeg in place of that. I also use half flour and half quick oats which is awesome and better for you. When I make multiple batches at a time, my ratio of oats is more than flour-so not an even 50/50.  I make a lot a once and just freeze them in gallon bags for super easy quick meals later!! Definitely a favorite from friends who are over too! I make these for lunch and dinner also!

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
All I changed ingredients-wise was replace all of the allspice with cinnamon (don't have any allspice right now). So in terms of texture these are freakin amazing!! I found them to be super fluffy which I like, but everyone else seems to say that they are dense. I sifted the flour, for no real reason, and just per my usual method of making pancake batter I mix until there are small lumps, let it sit for a few minutes, then gently mix again to break up the lumps. This seems to get everything incorporated nicely without overmixing and makes for a light and airy batter. Oh and they taste amazing as well.

None
text:
These pancakes were really good. They are not perfect looking like AR fluffy pancakes, but they sure do have a nice pumpkin flavor. I believe I used Trader Joes canned organic pumpkin puree. I halved the recipe and got 7 pancakes, but by the time I got to already cooking I realized I forgot the egg! No problem, they still turned out fine. I also could not find my allspice, so I subbed pumpkin spice for that one spice and followed the other 2. My only advice is to not cook them too high and make sure the centers are completely done. Mine took a little longer than typical pancakes to cook all the way through. I will make these again. I like how little sugar they use and the added nutrition from the pumpkin puree. I read in the new Allrecipes magazine that they are MyPlate approved too.

These are so good! I used 1/2 whole wheat flour and 1/2 all-purpose flour and added a few drops of vanilla and a dash more of the spices. text:
A deliciously perfect twist on traditional pancakes!  My allspice was expired, so I made up my own batch with cinnamon, nutmeg and cloves. I also combined the vinegar into the milk and let it sit for 5 minutes before adding to the other wet ingredients. The overall pumpkin flavor was subtle, which was fine by me, but next time I will double the spices as I LOVE a lot of spice. I really appreciate a fluffy pancake and the texture was spot-on. Even my pumpkin-hating hubby gobbled down a couple, and 4 year-old DD and I SCARFED these down! I foresee these fluffy pancakes as a regular weekend breakfast staple during the fall/winter months. The toppings and/or add-ins are endless: sauteed apples or pears, sweetened pumpkin flavored whipped cream, a cream cheese or real maple glaze, raisins, chocolate chips, nuts.....

text:
these are perfect, as is.

i mix the milk and vinegar together first and let it sit (so it turns into buttermilk) while i put together the dry ingredients, then i add the rest of the wet ingredients to the milk.  i have five children, so i double the recipe and use a 15 oz can of pumpkin. 

the batter is thick, but all you have to do is spread the batter out a bit with the back of the 1/4 measuring cup that you use to ladle it out.  

absolutely fabulous!  and it makes lots!

text:
I loved these-it IS a thick batter, but I found (as others suggested) if I just even out the batter in the skillet right after I pour the batter in, AND ensure I brown the pancake on both sides, it cooks- and tastes great. I've never seen a fluffier pancake. I did use melted butter, rather than the oil since I don't care for the flavor of canola oil, etc. The second time I made these, I couldn't find my allspice so I substituted several gratings of fresh nutmeg-and I liked that version too! (I also made a 1/2 recipe by halving everything-except the egg which I used one whole egg-and the recipe was great-and just enough for about 5-6 good-sized pancakes. BTW I just added the vinegar to the liquids mixture-no problem with curdling (as another reviewer had expressed concern with) Thanks for sharing this one!

These were delicious served with maple syrup. For anyone planning on using homemade pumpkin puree, instead of the canned, I recommend using 1-1/2 cups pumpkin puree (as long as it's been blended smooth) and reduce the amount of milk to 1 cup. Instead of adding all the spices separately, I just added 2-1/2 teaspoons pumpkin pie spice. My 11-month old loved it and so did I.

text:
Put the vinegar into the milk and let it rest for 5 minutes, then mix the ingredients according to the directions.  The vinegar/milk mixture is a substitute for buttermilk.  If you decide to use buttermilk in place of the milk, then omit the vinegar.  I also added a teaspoon of vanilla into the pumpkin mixture.  Amazing recipe!

Review:
Rating:

dateLastModified:
2011-05-31T08:41:47.78
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
3346050
Display Name:
Choculita
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
14
favoritesCount:
69
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great with 1/4 cup chopped pecans!  Use butter in the skillet or add to the pancakes afterwords to greatly enhance the flavor.  These are hearty, fluffy pancakes.  DO spread/flatten the batter on the skillet.  If you don't thin it with milk, don't expect to see bubbles rise to the surface as the pancakes cook - it won't happen.  Just watch it and flip when underside is golden brown.  Thinning with milk or buttermilk works fine too, but it does thin the flavor a bit too.  But most of pumpkin flavor is in the spices anyway.
It doesn't say what kind of vinegar to use - I used apple cider vinegar & will do so again. I think it brings out the pumpkin flavor.
This recipe is great any time of year!  As with all pancakes, mix wet ingredients into dry until just moistened and a bit lumpy.  Add pecans or  chocolate chips.  Thanks Ruth!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were delicious! After reading other reviews I made a few tweaks.  I used whole wheat pastry flour, 2 Tbsp baking powder and no baking soda, 1 Tbsp cinnamon and 2 tsp Pampered Chef Cinnamon Plus (it's kinda like allspice).  I served them with brown butter cinnamon syrup. Incredible! To make the syrup, in a sauce pan over medium heat, cook 1/2 cup butter for 8-10 min or until golden brown.  Stir occasionally.  Add 1/4 c maple syrup, 1/2 tsp cinnamon, 1/4 tsp nutmeg and 1/2 cup chopped toasted pecans.

These were very good!  Perfect for pumpkin season (and any other season)!  I added pecans to some while they were cooking, and those were perfect. text:
This a tasty pancake recipe. I had to add a little extra milk (1/4 cup), because the batter was too thick (even spreading them with a spatula, it's too thick, and they burn before bubbling enough to turn). The end result, while tasty, is a bit squooshy in the middle. The main picture for this recipe (which has been the main picture for a long time) is not a user-submitted picture (scan through them - it's not there) and is, IMO, not a picture of this recipe. This is important because if you believe you're going to get round dry pancakes, you're going to be disappointed -- these are misshapen, moist pancakes, so browse through the other photos -- they're more accurate to what your result will be. I would up the cinnamon also in the future. These will taste fantastic with a caramel syrup. Thanks for the recipe! (P.S. This recipe was tested with canned Libby's. Homemade pumpkin puree will be wetter, and thus may not require additional milk.)
Review:

5

text:
We make this gluten free, just do a direct exchange for the flour with Bobs Red Mill All Purpose Baking Flour (this is the only recipe I ever use the stuff for and it works well and hides the bean flavor of the blend.) So if your GF and missing pumpkin pancakes try this one, its fantastic! One last thing... you MUST eat it with REAL maple syrup, seriously, the fake stuff just won't cut it with these yummy pancakes!

userID:
4401195
Display Name:
Rachxl
isPro:

followersCount:
10
followingCount:

17
favoritesCount:
312
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/432148.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
so moist and delicious! these pancakes need an emphasis on the CAKE.  in fact, my stack seemed to melt together into a spicy pumpkin cake while I was eating them, and didn't really need any butter or syrup (although they were amazing with a little of both).   they are quite tricky to flip, especially if you add extra pumpkin like I did. I also added pumpkin spice seasonings and cloves along with the spices that were called for, and a little lemon zest to the dry ingredients.    DO NOT be afraid to add milk, especially if you were generous with the spices. I made a few without added milk and the dough was so sticky it was impossible to flip. I added about a half cup more to the rest of the batter to make it an easier consistency and the rest of my pancakes were just as delicious, and came off the pan much more neatly.

None
text:
Really good recipe, but I made some changes: I used 1 cup milk and 1 1/4 cups flour, but left all the other measurements as they are (except brown sugar I used maybe 2 1/2 tbsp).  I also used apple cider vinegar, which worked great. The result was a more moist and fluffy pancake with a terrific, juicy pumpkin flavor (I always use fresh, boiled or roasted pumpkin). I also put some nutmeg in and of course, added more cinnamon. In some of them I also added 100% pure cocoa chocolate chips, which are very bitter, and are absolutely delicious when combined with the spicy pancake and the sweet maple syrup.  Mmm-hmm!

text:
These pancakes were some of the best pancakes I have ever tasted. Even better then restaurant pumpkin pancakes. I also tweeked the recipe to make it gluten and dairy free. Instead of flour I used gluten free pancake mix (so I omited the baking powder and baking soda) and rice milk in place of the cows milk. I can't imagine that either of these changes would alter the taste.  These were so good. I can't wait to eat them again. Even my 2 year old liked them, and he isn't really a fan of pancakes. Thank you for the recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The best pancakes I have ever tasted, bar none. Follw the reviews not to add any more milk: the batter is supposed to be thick and so I pour it as a circle into my nonstick, and spread it a little to get it into good shape. Very filling and delicious. I think it's necessary to lightly grease the pan with butter for each pancake, and to cokk it a little longer than regular pancakes. I like them best plain or with a little butter but no syrup--I used pumpkin pie mix can instead of plain pumpkin puree and the batter was wonderfully sweet and spiced when I added a ts of cinnamon and loads of fresh grated ginger, didn't have allspice. May add some raisins, pecans, or choc chips to the batter next time. I like it best served with steaming cups of unsweetened coffee with a little milk, and fresh fruit on the side-- strawberries and grapes, next time I'll do peaches. May try another egg to give it a more egg-y taste( most pancakes do have 2 eggs) but it's not necessay. AWESOME!

text:
Very tasty! I made some adjustments to the recipe based on ingredients I had available and nutrtition!   I subbed applesauce for the oil, halved the sugar (topped w/ syrup, it doesn't need the extra sweetness), wheat flour, I used almond milk b/c that's all I had and I even used a bit extra to thin out the very thick batter some. It made 10 very dense 6" pancakes.   The flavor was quite good but a little dense for my liking. Will continue to tweak!

These are definitely better than plain pancakes but could be improved.  They turned out very dense and rubbery, even though I made sure not to overbeat them.  I had to add milk to thin the batter as it was way too thick!  They also had an overpowering taste of baking soda.  Next time, I think I'll add another egg, increase the spices and sugar, add vanilla, use more pumpkin, and use apple cider vinegar instead of white.

text:
Wow! These were fantastic. After reading the reviews, I added an extra egg to the batter. Keeping the portions to 1/4 c. and spreading it out ensured they cooked beautifully. They had great texture and flavor. I served it with Maple pumpkin syrup.  Mix 1/2 c. pure maple syrup with 1/2 c. or so pumpkin puree and a pinch of cinnamon. Heat it up until warm. Adds the perfect touch to these pancakes!

text:
We made these pancakes for our Christmas breakfast and they were a big hit!  I did make a couple of changes.  I used 1/4 c (4 T) brown sugar and added an extra egg.  I also omitted the ginger (heartburn sufferer) and added 1 more t cinnamon & 1 t vanilla.  These pancakes turned out fluffy and light and tender.  Another plus was that while I normally pretty much drown my pancakes in syrup, I found I enjoyed these best with just a drizzle.  Thanks for a great recipe!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe made nice thick, fluffy pancakes but I did tweak it. The batter was very thick. I remember hearing that seltzer water makes matzo balls fluffier, so I thinned the batter with some seltzer water. I probably used to 1/4-1/2 cup to thin out the thick batter. Also, next time I'd halve the amount of allspice and use a little less cinnamon. I used a 1/4 cup scoop and got 15 pancakes out of this recipe. I cooked them over moderate heat to make sure they were cooked through.

I thought WoW, I'm one of the few who didn't care for this recipe but on reading reviews I noticed people changed up this recipe often and then gave them 5 star ratings; some even using pancake mix and adding pumpkin and spice, while others used buttermilk, wheat flour and other things.  I followed the directions with exception of not having enough baking powder so I used a lil more baking soda; maybe this was my problem!  My son tasted one bite and said "I don't like them" and he'll eat anything with syrup on it!  We agree'd it's the texture and taste. The batter wasn't sweet or salty enough on it's own, I tasted the pancake plain and it just wasn't good... I'd up salt and sugar if I were to try them again.  Threw them away...

I definitely will be making this again!

country:

text:
This is a great recipe.  I, too, used buttermilk and omitted the vinegar, but added 1/4 tsp. of baking soda.  I also used self-rising flour (omitting the baking powder and salt).  I also added 1/8 tsp. each nutmeg and cloves.  I made a few pancakes with the thick batter, then added a few tablespoons (I didn't measure) of milk to thin it down.  The taste and texture of the pancakes didn't appear to be altered, only the thickness.  I chopped up some pecans and added to the batter (I love nuts in my pancakes) - yummy!  I will have to experiment further, though, because this recipe made 15 4" pancakes - way too many for the two of us.  This recipes goes in my file of favorites!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had very good luck with this recipe and will defintely use it again. I added about 1/2 teaspoon of vanilla, and maybe an 1/8 teaspoon of both nutmeg and cloves. I used buttermilk instead of milk (and therfore omitted the vinegar). The batter was a little thicker than I'm used to, so I diluted with a bit of fat-free half n half, and added a few extra tablesppoons of pumpkin to compensate (I didn't want to lose the pumpkin flavor) I realize these are not insignificant changes and therefore skew my review, but with these changes the pancakes were absolutely fantastic. I topped them off with bananas sauteed in butter, brown sugar, vanilla and grand marnier--defintely not necessarily, but a wonderful addition. The whole family raved about this breakfast for days.

text:
I think the consistency of the batter depends on how runny your pumpkin is.  An off-brand I have is really runny pumpkin, but Libby's is really thick.

That said, I made this with Ener-G egg replacer and used the equivalent of two eggs and just a little bit more milk.   My kids LOVED having this for breakfast on Thanksgiving day.  My husband and I also enjoyed them.  We had them with real maple syrup.  They were more filling than normal pancakes and we ended up with about half of them leftover.  

It made about 20 pancakes using a 1/4 cup scoop.

text:
I loved these pancakes!  I had leftover pumpkin from Thanksgiving pies, and this was the perfect way to use it!  I added a little extra milk to thin the batter, because it was quite thick, and I added some chocolate chips for taste.  This made a huge batch of batter, much more than the three of us needed.  I added some more flour and sugar (about 3/4 c flour, 1/2 c sugar, but it would depend on how much batter you have left over), and more chocolate chips,  to thicken the batter to cookie dough consistency. I dropped them on a cookie sheet and baked for about 12 minutes at 350 degrees.  The cookies and the pancakes were both great!  Thanks for such an easy and versatile recipe!

These are the most incredible pancakes I have ever had. I didn’t have vinegar, so I used lemon juice. However, that was the only substitution I made. I definitely did not over mix it.

text:
As many others have mentioned, when the recipe is followed, the batter is very thick a takes forever to cook through. I turned down the heat and let them cook until they were done. Unfortunately,  they were no longer pancakes at that point, but could better be described as "cakes." I was also not impressed with the taste.

I added some sugar, cinnamon and cloves, and put the rest of the batter into a greased muffin tin and baked them for 25 - 30 minutes at 325°F. They make delicious muffins !

text:
I made these exactly as the recipe specified (no tweaks) and they were amazing!  I was really surprised - I expected them to be flat and gummy, but they rose up like regular pancakes.  They are a bit denser than regular pancakes due to the pumpkin (don't expect them to be exactly the same as regular pancakes) but oh, so delicious!!!  One tip I will share is that these need to cook a little bit longer than regular pancakes, so be patient.  I had batter left over, so I put it in the refrigerator.  I took it out this morning, gave it a good stir and cooked up another batch.  They rose even higher this morning!  Delish!!!  Definitely a recipe I will keep!  Thank you for posting it, Ruth!

Normally I read reviews before trying new recipes on here, but this one time I was just looking spur-of-the-moment for a pancake recipe that included some canned pumpkin. This one was unfortunately a bad choice for me. I really wish I had seen where people had said “this is great with some tweaking” and also the ones who said “don’t thin the batter” though I don’t think that would’ve helped much... My husband and I were unable to eat what resulted from this recipe (and he will seriously eat ANYTHING).  Admittedly I did substitute almond milk because I didn’t have regular milk, but that shouldn’t affect things drastically. Although now I’m thinking maybe it did? Milk + vinegar to simulate buttermilk?  If that’s the idea, I feel the recipe should really have stated that. And then of course after the first couple were so crazy thick I thinned the batter with water until it was a little tiny bit closer to the consistency I’m used to.  But (after we made ALL of the batter into what appeared to be passable, nicely cooked pancakes) what we wound up with were overly-chewy yet suspiciously moist in the middle. Like, not-cooked-all-the-way-through moist. Even tried popping one or two in the microwave for a bit to see if they could be salvaged that way, but they were just totally unpalatable. I’m sure this recipe works fine with tweaks. I’m sure the recipe author makes perfectly edible pancakes - maybe I would even like them. But I don’t feel the recipe as-written gave me proper expecta

userID:
17139037
Display Name:
Mrjffwilhelm
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
49
favoritesCount:
104
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Not bad Pumpkin Pancakes,  The reason I said "not bad" is because when I saw vinegar in a pancake recipe, I thought, "ewe! how gross!" and the pancakes were going to have a vinegar taste. I did taste the batter and it had that vinegar taste, but after cooking them, and eating them I could not taste the vinegar.  I really do not know what the vinegar does in a pancake mix, but this is a new concept to me.  
So I did make it according to the recipe and the pumpkin pancakes were pretty good I must say. I would make them again.  I did use real pumpkin (not canned) in which, after carved, I cut the pumpkin in huge cubes and boiled on the stove for 2 to three hours on low to medium heat until soft.  Then I drained the pumpkin and used an electric mixer until it became a puree.  I added the puree into the mix and then followed the rest of the recipe.  I did use 1tsp of pumpkin pie spice in place of the allspice, cinnamon, and ginger. I mixed the dry with the wet and with an ice cream scoop, I scooped the batter and put in on the hot griddle.  
Recommendation:  If you have some pecans, chopped them up finely. When you put the batter on the griddle, sprinkle the pancakes with the chopped pecans. This gives it a nice compliment flavor.  Also, make an Apple Cider Syrup to drizzle on top.  Add your favorite coffee blend with Pumpkin creamer or a glass of apple cider; talk about a nice Fall Breakfast.

5

None
text:
These turned out perfectly! So fluffy and delicious, not overwhelmingly pumpkin or spice, but just right. The batter was a bit thick, but I used it as it was, just spreading it a bit thinner as I put it on the griddle, and the pancakes cooked up nicely browned on the outside and tender and cakey, not doughy, on the inside. I had bought some pumpkin butter from Trader Joe's, and it was perfect on the pancakes instead of syrup (although they were great with maple syrup, as well). Hearty enough that we made for a "breakfast for supper" meal.
