text:
We loved these pancakes, they are so flavorful you don't even need bacon! Note: the batter turns out thick, but as other reviewers have recommended, do NOT thin the batter with more milk bc it will dilute the flavor...and understandably our pancakes were thick but yummy.  I doubled the recipe (yielding around 17-18 (5") pancakes) so we'll have enough for dinner one night this week! All in all, a very filling, satisfying breakfast; one we will definitely make again!

text:
These are great! I used buttermilk, and still added the vinegar, and they turned out perfect. Batter is a little thick, be sure to spread it some when you put it on the griddle. I added some chopped pecans to the tops of the uncooked side, then flipped...very tasty addition. I hate to get up in the morning to measure, etc, so I mixed all the dry ingred and wet ingred separately the night before, then all I had to do was combine them in the morning....easy-peasy!

text:
My kids request pancakes every weekend and I was trying to get rid of old stuff in the pantry (canned pumpkin never used at Thanksgiving) so this recipe was a win-win. 
Armed with a can of pumpkin puree and a dream I started without making sure we had everything, per usual. 
Ended up having to substitute:
- milk with unsweetened vanilla almond milk
- applesauce for oil
- pumpkin pie spice for allspice
Not sure how the substitutions affected the end result since this was the first time, but they turned out great. Excited to make them again with WHITE CHOCOLATE CHIPS!

text:
Very good!  I had fresh pumpkin left from baking Thanksgiving pumpkin pies.  Fresh is best if you can.  I did not use allspice because I wanted to control the spice, so I did cloves, ginger, nutmeg (1/4 tsp each) and kept the cinnamon as is.  Beat my egg before I added it to the batter and went to town.  Winner winner chicken dinner!  Kids loved it!  Super moist pancakes and full of flavor.  I added chocolate chips to the last of the batter.  Kids loved that too.  It’s like ranch dressing for pancakes.  Very good recipe.  Fluffy, flavorful pancakes, not at all dense.

I followed the recipe exactly. They turned out wonderful. They were light, fluffy and moist. and I got rave reviews from all our relatives-adults and children. The thicker texture worked well for me as I could easily manipulate the perimeter to make perfectly shaped pancakes that usually run all over. My husband did say he wished they would have been more "pumpkiny". The flavor was mild but that worked for me so you could still taste the topping. I topped with cinnamon applesauce (yummy!!) I'll definitely make these again

text:
Absolutely delicious! I substituted 1/2 cup of the flour with whole wheat flour, as I often do when I make pancakes, but it made it a bit more heavy than I'd like, when combined with the pumpkin, so next time I think I'll just stick with the regular flour. I also added some pumpkin pie spice (based on the suggestion of another commenter), along with the listed spice ingredients. The flavor is great! I also had many leftover to freeze. I definitely look forward to making these again.

text:
I made it vegan and sugar-free with the following changes: used unsweetened original-flavor almond milk instead of cow's milk, used a flax egg (1 Tbsp ground flax + 3 Tbsp water, mixed, and let sit for 5 mins) instead of a chicken egg, and omitted the sugar (since I figured I'd add syrup to the top anyway).  We also used whole wheat flour because that's all we had.  These pancakes turned out soooo good.  There are only 2 in our household and we had leftovers for 2 more days, and they reheated in a frying pan just fine.

text:
Good pancakes in general.  The directions are missing some important steps.  The point of the Vinegar is to add it to the milk to curdle it; you need to add it to the milk about 5 minutes  before you add the milk to the rest of the ingredients.    I modified the recipe by using melted butter instead of oil and added 1/2 tsp of nutmeg.

I've made these at least 3 times in the past 2 months. That's how good they are. I just add a bit more brown sugar and  cinnamon.  I was looking for a recipe that matched if not  succeeded Denny's and boy did these hit the bull's-eye. These are better! Try them you won't regret it.  I store them in sets of two in the  freezer and put them in the  toaster for breakfast and they are as good as new.

Made these with changes. Opted for lite coconut milk for the milk (what I had on hand) and combined whole wheat pastry flour and white wheat flour for the AP. Used pumpkin pie spice (trying to use this up forever!) in place of the individual spices. And apple cider vinegar. Made a 1/2 recipe but kept the whole egg, so I guess it would be 2 eggs for a whole recipe. We thought the texture was fine, like a pancake. And they puff up a lot. We ate them plain but maple syrup would be good too!

None
text:
These pancakes are great. The only change I made was to add 1/2 teaspoon cloves. I often add cloves to any recioe that calls for cinnamon and nutmeg or all spice. It just "pops" the flavor of the other spices. To those who changed the recipe by using pancake mix, please try the recipe as written with the flour, sugar, egg, etc. Taking the time to make as directed is well worth the few extra minutes it will take you. Since this recipe will not use the entire  can of pumpkin, just freeze what's leftover and use it to make a half batch of the pancakes.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is an excellent start to the perfect pumpkin pancakes. A little light on the pumpkin flavor, as other reviewers have shared, so next time I try these, I'd like to double the pumpkin and add less milk so they're not too wet. Very, very moist, as all things pumpkin should be! Adding mini chocolate chips is an obvious and welcome tweak, and I much prefer freshly whipped cream on my pumpkin pancakes rather than syrup. Also note that sugar is actually a wet ingredient, so the brown sugar should be added to the milk and pumpkin mixture.

country:
None
text:
Great recipe! I followed some other reviewers suggestions and increased the pumpkin to 1 1/3c. I also mixed the brown sugar in with the wet ingredients, not the dry. I increased the cinnamon to 1 TBSP and added 1/2tsp of ground nutmeg (eliminating the allspice). I also omitted the vingear and instead used 1/3c vanilla soy milk (its what I had on hand). Lastly, I sprinkled chopped pecans into the freshly poured pancakes in the pan. YUM!!!

text:
This is a great basic recipe that can be tweaked for individual tastes and ingredients on hand. I adjusted the spices to my liking by increasing cinnamon to 2 tsp and omitting the others. I had a very thick butternut squash soup base on hand and used it instead of pumpkin. (Most canned pumpkin is actually other types of squash). We are a gluten free family, thus I substituted my own gluten free flour blend cup for cup. I used 1 cup + splash of milk for the proper consistency as well.

text:
They are tasty! But medium high is way too high. They burned super fast with the inside too doughy. I turned it down to medium and it was perfect. The consistency is nowhere near normal pancakes, so don't wait till they're all bubbled to flip them, or they'll be black. The batter is super thick. But once you figure out the right heat, they taste great!

text:
The first time I made these, I made them almost exactly (I used up some pampered chef cinnamon blend for the total spice amount-same amount though).  The next time, I forgot about the pumpkin shortage.  So, I microwaved a sweet potato and used that.  I also realized, after we ate, that the vinegar was still sitting in it's little cup.  I added another tsp of spice blend.  They were BETTER!!!  They still rose beautifully.  Not sure if it was the lack of vinegar, the sweet potato or the extra spices but yummy!  I will make them this way from now on.  A sweet potato is pretty simple to nuke....8-10 minutes for one that will yield a cup of meat.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-08-28T15:49:40.077
helpfulCount:
0

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe many times.  Tonight, however, for the first time, I used non-sugar sweeteners in the batter and baked it into a sheet cake rather than making pancakes.  For sweetener I used erythritol and stevia drops, and I also always use whole-wheat flour.  To counteract the extra bitterness and stronger flavor of this flour, I also always end up using a lot more spice and sweetener than the recipe calls for (3-4x the amt. given in the recipe).  Finally, I always double this recipe, and use 1 can of pumpkin puree for the whole thing instead of only using 1 cup then having some leftover in the can.  Anyway, it turned out GREAT and I'd recommend this recipe to anyone.  Delicious!!

text:
Here's the thing... I love these pancakes and make them all the time BUT they frustrate me all the time too. They always seem uncooked in the middle and are never a fluffy pancake. That being said I freeze them individually and microwave them as needed. Once microwaved they are fine and no longer "doughy" inside. I've tried a million different variations of this recipe to avoid the doughy inside but no matter what they never really fluff the way they should. But I keep coming back to this recipe because it makes me feel better giving my kids these pancakes rather than traditional ones and the flavors are great... Oh the dilemma lol...

text:
Good golly miss Molly, these were yummy! The batter was as thick as mollsses on a cold day. I added probably about an extra quarter to half cup of milk. I also made them "whole grain" by swapping the flour as follows: 1 cup whole wheat flour, 1/4 cup ground flax, 1 cup of all purpose flour. Due to the thickness I cut into them to make sure they were done. The knife came out gooey the first time so I flipped them again until the knife came out just a tiny bit moist. The four year old loved them and so did the wife. Yum-a-licous. Served with whipped cream and real maple syrup. Plenty of leftovers to toast for breakfast during the week.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Maybe one reason why this wasn't perfect is because I doubled this recipe and "eyeballed" the ingredients. Even after adding more flour, baking soda, and baking powder (which is where I thought my problem lay),  I realized another reason why the pancakes would brown on the outside and remain wet on the inside: the pumpkin. It's so wet, yet there's still a ton of milk in the recipe. Or at least, that's the best reason I can come up with.

Since the pancakes were too wet to flip, I started using the batter for waffles, and that worked much better. Still a little wet, but delicious. I'll definitely make these on Thanksgiving (as waffles) with whipped cream on top!

text:
Excellent recipe! I've made these for a few years and would highly recommend them to anyone. 

Makes roughly 12 cakes. The bit about mixing liquids and dry separately and then combining is a must! The first time I made these I confused the baking powder qty with baking soda qty, that was not a crowd pleaser. The next time I mixed everything together at once, and that made the cakes a little more "doughy" than third time when I mixed liquid and dry separately. 

Excellent recipe! Thanks for sharing with the world

text:
Great recipe for Halloween morning!

I made it egg-free by mixing 1 tablespoon of flaxseed meal with 3 tablespoons of water in a small bowl. Let it sit for a few minutes and use it in place of the egg. 

Also cheated by using a couple teaspoons of pumpkin pie spice in place of all the spices. 

I used apple cider vinegar but I'm really not sure it made any difference.

text:
I used Namaste GF  Waffle and Pancake Mix. These were VERY good! I also blended all wet ingredients in a cuisinart as recommended by another person. Then I blended the wet into the dry with a whisk to break up large clumps. GF flours are tricky. I think you could cut back on the milk. Mine were thinner than I expected, but still tasted great! Using a 1/4 cup to spoon the mixture into the griddle made for uniform pancakes. Topping them with homemade whipped cream and candied pecans made them AMAZING!

userID:
12558321
Display Name:
90bjdh
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:

madeRecipesCount:
9
favoritesCount:
4
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fabulous! My family eats a lot of pancakes so I always make big batches and freeze them so they can just pull them out and heat and eat! Well most pancakes are fairly dull as well as the usual add ins. I have been looking for something a little different and I thought pumpkin! I like pumpkin but not pumpkin pie so I have been looking for random recipes. Found this and thought sounds good. I made a few tweaks though. I used 2 eggs, 1TBS  cinnamon, 1tsp each clove and nutmeg as well as 2tsps vanilla and 1TBS white sugar. I mixed dry ingredients 1st. In a separate bowl whisked the pumpkin puree by itself before adding the other wet ingredients. Then I combined it all, let sit for 5-10min then did about 1/4C for each pancake. It is a thick batter but spread it out and it's fine. They turned out fantastic and this made 26 2-3inch pancakes.

We really enjoyed these pancakes. I substituted soy milk for regular milk so that it was dairy free, and I increased the cinnamon a little because I like cinnamon. The batter was so thick that I couldn't even spread it, so I had to thin it out with a little more soy milk. The pancakes tasted good, but I didn't like the ginger in them. I agree with the reviewer who recommended skipping the allspice and ginger and adding in some nutmeg instead while increasing the cinnamon. That's what I plan on doing next time.

text:
Every year when we're at the shore, we go to Uncle Bill's for pancakes, and they have the most amazing pumpkin pancakes, served with cinnamon butter and whipped cream.  My daughter loves them.  So I told her I would try and make them when we got home this year.  This recipe was a good base, but I did as one reviewer stated and added more pumpkin, deleted the vinegar and ginger, and added more cinnamon and nutmeg.  I'm glad i did up the spices, because these would have been pretty bland.  Next time I may up the spices even more.  They  were delicious, dense pancakes and I served them with cinnamon butter (from this site), whipped cream and maple syrup.  My daughter said they tasted like Uncle Bill's!  I will definitely make these again, but with all the changes.

text:
I am giving these pancakes 5 stars because my son LOVES!!! these pancakes.  He wants to eat them everyday!  I on the other hand have such a hard time making them, it's crazy! I make them every weekend and a few times I had to throw out a whole batch a few burned a few were raw in the middle I tried so many different ways of cooking them. I have a griddle in the middle of my stove and I used oil and they burned and stuck to the griddle. I tried butter and lowered the flame and they were raw.  I tried a cast iron skillet same problem.  Finally I tried butter and cooking spray and this seems to work the best.  The pancakes do not rise as high as I would like but who cares about me as long as my son loves them then I am giving them a 5!!!

Tried this recipe this morning before work. Used canned pumpkin which was about one and a half cups so I adjusted everything else 1.5 times. I guessed at the 1.5 eggs. Used half wheat and half white flour. Also used apple cider vinegar instead of white just because it was closer and I was in a hurry. Also dumped everything into one bowl and mixed. Left my husband to add extra milk to thin the batter as he saw fit. Consistency of the final product was just fine. Next time I will add more spice or pumpkin pie spice as I like a little more zip in my pumpkin pancakes. Topped with real maple syrup. DELICIOUS!

text:
Made these for the kids this morning. Light and fluffy! But I used 1 cup whole grain spelt flour in place of one cup of white flour (milder and lighter than whole wheat flour), and added 2t white sugar in addition to the brown sugar (to make it palatable for the kids), omitted the ginger and allspice (too strong for the kids), and put in 1t pumpkin pie spice. Super fast and easy, and with common ingredients. Nice fall breakfast!

text:
Changes were: Used 1 C. whole wheat pastry flour, 1 C. reg. flour, 2 T. cinnamon, 1/2 tsp. nutmeg and around 1/2 tsp. pumpkin pie spice, and 1 1/2 C. pumpkin, 1/3 C. ch. pecans.  Didn't add allspice, vinegar or ginger.  Did 3 T. brown sugar, 2 t. baking powder, 1 tps. baking soda.  Added 2 eggs and 2 T. oil Put spoon of batter in pan and spread it out w/spoon.  They were light & fluffy. Recipe amt. is huge, could definitely cut in 1/2 for 2 of us.

text:
I modified this by substituting 1/3 whole wheat flour and adding ginger, toasted pecans, and ground flaxseed. The pecans sort of lost their texture--walnuts might hold up better. Other users urge not adding more milk, but as made, I had trouble getting these to cook all the way through--the batter is dense and does not flow, so these thick pancakes were sometimes still gooey in the middle. Keep them small and distribute the batter with a spoon to flatten slightly. Very tasty and filling, though, and my husband LOVED them.

country:
None
text:
Super moist (not gooey) and delicious! Also filling--I only needed one. You can definitely taste the pumpkin, and it was perfect on a Saturday morning with hot coffee. I am a vegan so used my usual substitutes-- 2 TB flax meal instead of one egg, and organic soy milk instead of cow's milk. Also didn't have all purpose flour so used whole wheat. Word of advice: the batter is super thick (may want to add milk as needed) and when on the pan it's thick enough that it may not bubble through, so routinely check on the underside so it doesn't burn.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We had breakfast for dinner today to mix things up...as I was craving pumpkin pancakes for the past few days and saw this recipe this morning and went out to buy all the ingredients.  I could wait until breakfast the next morning to make these.  By the way, I practice the alkaline diet, but really wanted pancakes since it is fall and I have a hard time getting my toddlers to eat veggies.  So this is a great way to hide the veggies in the pancakes.  So I did quite a bit of substituting and my rating is based on the substitute version and I always use organic everything.  I replaced buttermilk for the milk, I cooked a pumpkin to make my own pumpkin puree, used homemade apple sauce for the oil, apple cider vinegar for the vinegar, whole wheat flour for the flour (next time I'll try 1 cup wheat flour and 1 cup of ground oats), added one extra tbl of brown sugar (next time I'll use coconut sugar, it is the healthy version of sugar), replaced the ginger with pumpkin pie spice, and replaced vanilla extract for the allspice, next time I'll add 1 tbl of fresh lemon juice.  This recipe can hide 2 veggie and 1 fruit serving in the pancakes for the kids! hehe

text:
These pancakes were delicious! As suggested by another user, I put all the wet ingredients, along with the brown sugar and the spices, in my blender and I blended it all up until it was smooth. I then whisked it into the dry until it was well blended. The batter is a little thick, but if you scoop them out with 1/4 cup and spread the batter around a bit, they turn out so good. I also added another tablespoon of brown sugar and a bit more cinnamon, but those were the only changes I made. It's almost like eating pumpkin bread in pancake form. Would also be good with semi-sweet mini chocolate chips in them. Thanks for the recipe! It's a keeper.

text:
The recipe as is, is just okay. I followed all directions and found it was not sweet or "pumpkin" enough. I added a half tablespoon of nutmeg, about another 1/4 cup of pumpkin puree and about 1/3 cup of brown sugar and found it was more to my liking. Some of the reviews said the pancakes were too thick and doughy. I used a 1/4 cup scoop to measure the pancakes, flattening them out as I poured and I made 19 pancakes. I'm sure if I would've scraped the bowl real good, I could have made 20, but I was tired. I used honey butter and mmm, mmm, mmm, that was the kicker!

userID:
10993821
Display Name:
shorty123
isPro:

3
favoritesCount:
1
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614284.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The recipe is good with the following modifications:

Use 1 C whole wheat pastry flour and 1 C flour. Add 1t cinnamon, increase the ground ginger slightly and andd 1t vanilla extract. Use 1 1/3 C pumpkin puree. Mix the vinegar and milk together to sour the milk. Replace 1 T of the vegetable oil with 3 T ground flax seed. Add a dash of ground cloves. Add 1t molasses. Add some extra milk as needed to thin the batter out. When the batter is ladled into the pan, you need to push it down slightly with the bottom of the ladle to spread it out since the batter is thick. It is best to cook the pancake on a cast iron pan.

text:
I make these for my grandkids who absolutely love them!! The first time I made them, I followed the recipe and we thought they were wonderful. I wanted to make them more healthy so I used whole wheat pastry flour instead of all purpose flour and I use rice milk instead of milk (milk allergy). I also froze fresh pumpkin so I use that instead of canned. The texture is a little different but they taste great. The kids (ages 1 and 3) adore them with a little applesauce on the top. I usually make a double batch and then freeze them, they warm up nicely in the microwave.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I took this as a starting point, but changed it a bit with awesome results.  Mixed 2 cups flour, 1.5 tsp baking soda, 1.5 tsp baking powder, 1/2 tsp salt.  In a separate bowl, mashed with fork 1.5 cups freshly baked pumpkin (baked at 375F x 1 hr, cooled).  Added 1 egg, mashed, added about 1 Tbs coconut oil, mashed.  Half cup at a time, added 1.5 cups whey from home-made ricotta (so easy! - look it up).  Mixed well (beat with fork).  Added to dry stuff and mixed with wisk.  This came out way thick for pancakes, so I added probably another cup of whey.  Fried on low-medium 4 at a time 3-4 " pancakes.  Kids ate 'til they could eat no more. Yum! Thanks for the inspiration!

userID:
1016363
Display Name:
1JOHN513
isPro:

3

46

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614284.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were simply wonderful! I did make changes, cobbled together from several reviews. I used 1 c whole wheat flour, 1 c oats, 3 T brown sugar (we like them a little bit sweeter), 2 tsp baking powder, 1 tsp. baking soda, 1 T cinnamon, 1/4 tsp freshly grated nutmeg, 1/4 tsp ginger, 1/4 tsp salt. In a separate bowl, I gently beat the egg, added 1-1/2 c almond milk (we are allergic to cow's milk) and 1-1/3 cup pumpkin, slowly poured in 2 T melted butter, then added it all to the dry ingredients. The batter is VERY thick. I scooped it into the plan and flattened it with a wooden spoon. After flipping, flattened again. Note they take a long time to cook, I don't think they weren't done, I think maybe it was the moistness from the pumpkin, but we like them cooked so they weren't moist (felt undone) in the middle. If you want a thinner pancake, be sure to scoop a scant 1/4 batter so you can flatten them well. I learned if you scoop too much, they just won't flatten and you have a more puffy cake like pancake, which is not a bad thing. We just prefer them thinner. Also, this variation is not at all like a traditional pumpkin pancake, but if you are looking for a way to add whole grain deliciousness to a pumpkin pancake,this is the way to go. The oats give it a great texture...my teenaged son takes these to school in a baggie to eat cold at break or between classes.

text:
These are delicious! I didn't have allspice on hand, so I just left it out and put in one teaspoon of nutmeg...I just love cinnamon and nutmeg combined. Will definitely be making these again. I modify the temperature, however. I put the oil on medium heat and turn it down as low as possible after the oil gets hot. Give the pan a few minutes to cool back down before you put the batter in. The cakes are ready to flip when there are air bubbles all over. The first pancake of any batch will ALWAYS turn out a little funky.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
As is, I'd give this recipe four stars. Our first batch wasn't sweet enough for our taste and didn't have much cinnamon or allspice flavor. The texture was great though. We tweaked the recipe the next time by increasing the cinnamon, brown sugar, and allspice considerably. I also added nutmeg and ground cloves, along with some Mexican vanilla and pecans. With those changes, I'd give it five stars. I love the added crunch of the nuts. We topped ours with the Cinnamon Cream Syrup from this site and also the cream cheese topping from the French Apple Pie with Cream Cheese Topping recipe. Both were amazing. This recipe is nice because you can change it to suit your own taste, and ours run a little more decadent. We'll make this again.

Display Name:
Mrf2218

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good, fluffy pancakes.  One comment calls for upping cinnamon to 3Tbs -- that's WAY too much!  Makes the final very dry (picture trying to swallow a spoonful of cinn!).  Original recipe calls for 1 tsp, maybe increase to 1 1/2 tsp.  A good addition is a touch of nutmeg (maybe 1/2 - 1 tsp), and increasing the amount of pumpkin to around 1 1/2 cups (particularly if using fresh pumpkin, like I did).  Finally, I found the pancakes themselves could be a little sweeter, and added 1 Tbs of white sugar (might depend on how sweet your pumpkin is).  One batch feeds our family of four nicely.

text:
yuuuuuummmmm!!!!!!!!!!! Just made these and they are amazing!
Took a few reviewers advice: added extra egg (sooo glad I did), added 1 1/2 teas vanilla, increased cinnamon to 2 teas, added in some dashes of ground cloves and nutmeg with other seasonings, followed rest as is. I let the batter stand for about 5 minutes before starting and let the griddle get really hot. Last time I made pumpkin cakes the batter was so thick so I was skeptically about a whole cup of pumpkin but I did it anyway and it was perfect....just dallop a bit on griddle and smooth out with spoon.
Seriously soo perfect !!!

country:
None
text:
Must try recipe.  I made few adjustments which made it a 10 star rating. Add one well ripped mashed banana, 1/4 tsp. cloves, & 1/4 tsp. fresh nutmeg. Let batter rest for 10 minutes and don't add any milk.  I also added chocolate chips and here is the trick. After you pour the batter, immediately sprinkle the chips and then softly push them in till they are no longer visible.  This way, they don't burn when you flip them over. Enjoy !! your family will love them.

None
text:
I made two adjustments on measurements and one procedural change. Pumpkin puree was increased to 1 1/2 cups. Cinnamon increased to 1 1/2 teaspoons. Vinegar only makes sense to me b/c I assume it's used w/ the milk to substitute for buttermilk. So I poured the vinegar into the milk and let it sit while I combined the dry ingredients and got the rest of the wet ingredients ready. Giving the milk and vinegar a few minutes is standard procedure. I liked the results very much and definitely will make again, keeping my changes.

userID:
8481109
Display Name:
agpowers
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made these on Christmas morning with my family. My picky, foodie family. Everyone took one, and, as I chewed nervously, they started RAVING about them. My dad (MY DAD!) went back for seconds. I couldn't believe it. They past the pickiest family test. Here are a couplet things I noted that could make them even better:
1. Make SURE to serve with warm, real (none of the fake stuff) maple syrup. I also put warmed frozen blueberries with them and I thought that was fabulous.

2. I think I made mine too thick, wanting big, beefy pancakes, but they were too dense. I'll easily fix this next time by flattening them out on the pan a little more.

3. I used half apple sauce and half oil to cut down on the fat and it seemed OK. Next time for comparison I'm going to try 2T butter.

4. I'm glad I didn't use half ww flour and half all purpose. I think ww would have made them borderline tough. Just serve with fruit and you'll get fiber there ;) Don't sacrifice the taste/texture for a little fiber.
Review:

4

text:
fantastic flavor!  good that they were not too sweet, because it balanced the maple syrup nicely.  very thick though, next time I'll try thinning them out with more milk, otherwise they can be a little gooey if you cook them too quickly/high heat (try lower heat, longer cooking time).  With my first batch, I put the cooked pancakes in the toaster oven to keep them warm until I was done making all of them, and it helped cook the insides a little longer.  We had leftover batter too, which was good the next day.  a keeper!!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674138.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great flavor. Some pumpkin recipes don't seem to have a spicy enough flavor for me but these do. Pretty thick dough.  I cooked mine and put them in the oven for a bit to get the dough totally cooked. Melted some butter with maple syrup with a pinch of cinnamon to pour over the top. Hubby loved them and I froze the rest. 
TIME SAVER: Just line up on wax paper, wrap three at a time, fold the ends up and several packets fit perfect in a gallon freezer bag. You can pull out 3 at a time and heat up for a quick morning breakfast. I do this with bacon (uncooked) also. Just pull a long strip of wax paper, lay out one strip, roll, lay out another, etc. I roll about 5-6 strips in a packet. Put in gallon freezer bag. I can just pull out 3-6 slices of bacon at a time already separated by wax paper. Prevents bacon from going bad in the fridge and the wax paper separates the frozen strips for easy cooking.

4

userID:
7912149
Display Name:
Melourn
isPro:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/722252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had to change the recipe pretty drastically on this one. The "original recipe" yielded pancake mix that was extremely liquid in nature, and when cooked, they came out thin, wet, and limp. The only redeeming factor was the pumpkin-pie-like taste.

While the original recipe calls for about 2 cups of flour, I think I added about 3 cups per each 2 cups I original started with (I am cooking for a lot of people). I also multiplied the Baking soda, baking powder, cinnamon, and brown sugar by the power of three for every called for amount.

Once tampered with, the recipe yielded far thicker mix and resulted in a fluffy, not too moist-not too dry, delicious pancake that I can't wait to share with everyone tomorrow. 

This is a great recipe to toy with, especially since it's winter-time!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2011-10-20T10:25:41.463
helpfulCount:

text:
I followed the recipe with only a minor change.  I added 2 tsp. cinnamon instead of 1.  Also, I didn't have allspice, so I added 1/4 tsp. nutmeg and 1/4 tsp. cloves.  I also added about 1/4 cup milk, and these pancakes were still thick and fluffy.  They were a little too thick without the added milk.  These really were absolutely delicious!  I will make these again!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm not really sure where the complaints come from. Yes the batter is very thick, but cooking them on low (kept my griddle on 350) will allow them to cook through but not burn. In addition, pumpkin itself doesn't really have a lot of flavor, so you would need to add spices to it to taste. Pumpkin is bland just on its own. I added a ton of allspice and more nutmeg than called for, and these came out light and tender. I didn't find them to be dense and chewy at all. On the contrary, they melt in your mouth.

text:
I'm not sure if it was because I used whole wheat flour instead of all-purpose, but the batter was very thick, so I had to use more milk to make it easily scoopeable. However, even then the batter was more breadlike. I even used the remaining batter (and there was a TON of it) to bake this as a bread. The flavor is probably more suitable as a sliced bread than a pancake, in my opinion. I wouldn't say the recipe was yummy, but it certainly has that Fall quality.

text:
Took some advice from the reviews, we did the following: used 2 eggs, 2 tsp cinnamon 2 tsp pumpkin pie spice, omitted ginger and all spice, 2 tsp baking soda, and added 3 TBS of melted butter. We also used QUINOA flour for a healthier option!! These were amazing pancakes, not too sweet and the quinoa gave them a slightly nutty taste as well!! The batter is very thick for a pancake batter, we just ladled out about 1/4 cup onto the griddle and quickly spread it a bit with the back of the ladle to make them a bit thinner and they were perfect and cooked all the way through!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These may become one of my favorite pancakes!  I thought I'd give it a try with some whole wheat flour (I did 1/2c WW and the rest all-purpose) but I don't think I'll do that again because they turned out somewhat flatter and I'm guessing that may be why?  They also took a long time to cook through and even still seemed to be doughy and not completely cooked through, and I let them cook for quite some time.  Not sure what the deal was.  I also did not have allspice, so I decided to just use pumpkin pie spice since it's pretty much the same thing, and since I wanted to add more spice in general (per suggestions) I used 3t. pumpkin pie spice and then added 1/2t. cinnamon for my spices.  It had great flavor.  I added chocolate chips to half of the batch and those were also delicious!!  Definitely a keeper of a recipe!!  It made about 18 small-medium pancakes too.

text:
Delicious!  I halved the recipe for 2 people (probably could have just made 1/3) and used half of the ingredients.  However, based on some other comments, I used a little more of each of the spices (+ nutmeg) and used just over 3/4 C of pumpkin puree.  My first batch wasn't stirred (after sitting while I heated up the skillet) and was thicker to pour than batch 2, in which the batter was stirred.  As suggested, I used ~1/4 cup and flattened them out.  I used a large disher (#20) and bet an ice cream scooper would work too.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were quite good.  I made them for Thanksgiving morning when I had leftover pumpkin puree.  I used whole wheat pastry flour, Splenda brown sugar substitute, and used applesauce for the oil to make them healthier.  I think next time I'll use pumpkin pie spice in place of the other spices and I might add some chopped pecans or chopped fresh cranberries. They did take quite a while to cook through because the batter is dense, but the flavor is excellent--tasted just like pumpkin pie (my husband loved them!).  I suggest letting the batter sit awhile to allow the baking soda to start lightning up the batter.  Spread the thick batter a bit with a spoon. The pancakes were surprising light, but filling.  It made a LOT of pancakes, so I froze them individually to microwave on a busier morning.  Thanks for a great recipe, Ruth!

text:
I just made these for the second time. Awesome! They are thick, hearty, pancakes. Instead of allspice I used nutmeg (1/2 t.) and ground cloves (1 t.) increased cinnamon to 1 Tablespoon and ground ginger to 2 teaspoons. I increased the brown sugar and the oil to 4 Tablespoons each. Also increased the baking powder and soda to 2 teaspoon each. Use whole milk, or even condensed milk and don't add too much!

text:
Doubled the recipe so I had some to freeze and pull out later for a quick breakfast. I already have a delicious pumpkin pancake recipe but there is about 3x as much fat in it, so I was looking for something a little healthier. This has a minimal amount of fat yet still delivers big taste and a very fluffy pancake. I even used half whole wheat flour and they were still quite fluffy, while still being thick and hearty so that you don't need to eat as many. Loved it topped with applesauce! So glad I have a better-for-us yummy pumpkin pancake recipe now!

These pancakes are fantastic. I've been making the original recipe for quite some time but switched it up today. For the flour I used 1c. AP flour, 1/2c. whole wheat flour, 1/2c. oats, applesauce for the oil and lemon juice for the vinegar.  Let the batter sit for 15 minutes before cooking, still incredibly yummy. I make extra batches to freeze to have on hand for a quick breakfast.  Thanks for a great recipe!!

text:
I have to add my 5 stars to this recipe; it was outstanding with the kids (with some of my usual adjustments for high altitude and boosting the recipe up to 7 cps of flour).  Regarding the thickness of the batter consistency, for any kind of pancakes I always add milk last to get the consistency I want, and I don't measure it.  In this case I used a bit more than a quart of milk for 7 cps flour, so I'm probably very close to the recipe proportions, but even a quarter cup makes a big difference (especially in the winter in CO with no humidity) in getting the batter thin enough to spread itself easily while keeping it intact.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2009-01-23T17:46:00.86

text:
Love love love! I do like a bit sweeter so I added 2TBS. brown sugar, 1/4 C pumpkin (because i wanted to use it up) and then eye balled a little more flour, a little more milk(i used rice milk by the way) and I added 1 tsp. vanilla as suggested by another member. And was it just me, but I got 14 1/4C. pancakes...give or take a little because I added a little more pumpkin, and milk and flour respectively??!! Geez.  But an AWESOME flavor...add chunks of pecans for a little extra flair.  No butter or syrup needed!  Which is good, because you will be eating a ton of the pancakes and that way you don't add the extra calories with the toppings. Just more pancakes. haha

Wow. These are delicious. I wish I had tried these sooner. Definitely great for pumpkin lovers like me. ;) Great plain and even cold. I must admit though. I didn't follow the recipe exactly. Though someday I'm going to try it completely with whole wheat flour as I prefer it over white.

text:
These were great!  I liked them a little thicker, so I added about a cup of batter and didn't flatten them out.  After we put the batter on the griddle, I added some ground flax, chopped walnuts and a little brown sugar.  Then when they were flipped over to finish cooking, the nuts toasted and the brown sugar caramelized.  Plus the nuts add some protein and fiber.

text:
These pancakes were a hit with my family.  They were not too sweet and did not have too strong of a pumpkin taste.  I used fresh pumpkin that we pureed ourselves from a baked pumpkin.  I also used freshly ground wheat flour with a tsp of gluten added.  I used Pumpkin Pie Spice instead of measuring everything out.  This recipe is definitely a keeper.  Often, things are a bit heavy with the freshly milled flour, but with this recipe, the pancakes came out fluffy and delicious!

text:
This is a very good recipe, I followed it per the instructions except I forgot to add in the brown sugar. We did not miss it at all! Topped it with some maple syrup, redi-whip and a sprinkle of pumpkin spice and it was DIVINE! A definite repeat for when I have some left over pumpkin. Thanks for the share =)

About a year later from the first time I made this here are a few modifications I made to work with a food allergy - sub the milk for vanilla soy milk, omitted the egg and used 1 c AP Flour and 1 c whole wheat flour with and additional 1 tsp of pumpkin spice. Got the maple syrup and agave from Trader Joes and sugar free redi-whip and it is BETTER than when we first made it, meets our allergy needs and a bit healthier - thanks again for the baseline recipe :)

This has been the best so far of all the pumpkin pancake recipes I have tried.  The first time I tried it I did the recipe to the T but was way to heavy for me and not enough spice kick.  The second time I made it I added an extra egg(which made them lighter) and used 1 1/2 teaspoons of pumpkin pie spice and a tablespoon of cinnamon used 2 tablespoons of brown sugar and 2 tablespoons of white sugar. Also a teaspoon of vanilla.
Yummy!!!

These are good but not amazing. The texture and pumpkin flavor was nice but I think I will add more sugar next time. I followed the recipe exactly but added a splash of pure vanilla extract. text:
AWESOME!  I felt like a star having been the person who made them.  I made some slight changes like substituting 1 3/4 C wheat flour for the 2 C all purpose flour called for in the recipe.  I also halfed the ginger tripled the cinnamon, used 1 3/4 - 2 C milk, and added 1 tsp vanilla extract, 1/2 tsp of clove and 1/2 tsp nutmeg.  I have now made them 5 or 6 times and my sometimes picky husband and 2 year old daughter LOVES them! To save time, I pre-mixed all the dry ingredients in a ziplock for the next time.  Good luck.

thanks for posting!!!

country:

text:
These are very hearty and quite good.  Great for feeding a crowd, and healthy too with the right ingredients.  I replaced 1/2 the flour with whole wheat graham flour and used canola oil.  I also used red wine vinegar, and you could not taste it.  These do brown up quickly and are so thick that it's hard to get the middles and sides done before they're brown.  I've found that if they're a little soft when they come off the griddle, stack them on a plate, and carryover cooking will finish them off.  We ate them warm, sprinkled with cinnamon sugar.  Like a yummy pumpkin donut, but better!

text:
This is certainly not a "Weekday Morning" recipe.  It takes FOREVER - but I'll tell ya, THESE ARE TOTALLY WORTH THE WAIT!! I did make a few changes... I used evaporated milk, an extra tbs of brown sugar, GOBS more spices (cloves, nutmeg, more cinn / ginger / allspice), I did add a generous splash of 1% milk to loosen up the batter a bit, and a heapin' spoonful of applesauce.  These changes were divine.  Will make again, only save it for a weekend when I feel like spendin' oodles of time in the kitchen.

I made these this morning and they were a hit! We topped them with fresh whipped cream and maple syrup. I saw baking pumpkins in the store recently, and can't wait to use some fresh puree! I also had issues with them not getting done in the middle, but found that I was using too much batter at once and not spreading thin enough. Once I cut down how much I was using, lowered the heat slightly, and spread it way out, they were PERFECT!

Display Name:

isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/3057.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a fantastic recipe!!! I used leftover pumpkin puree I made for pumpkin pies. They were spectacular! I would highly recommend this recipe. I had no problems with it being too thick. My children loved them and they are very picky. They were light, fluffy and very flavorful. I will make these pancakes again!
***an update*** I have been making these for awhile now. There are a few things I have learned: 1) If you use fresh pumpkin puree they turn out better than they do if you use canned. 2)If you use canned pumpkin, you MUST thin it a bit. I use apple juice (approx. 1/3 a cup) and it is wonderful! 3) If you substitute a pancake mix it will not be an amazing pancake. It just won't taste the same. It will be "OK", but don't expect much. It will be a 2 1/2 star pancake at best. 4) If you substitute pumpkin pie spice, it is wonderful but just as good as the spice combo they recommend.
I hope this helps someone. :)
Review:
Rating:
4

text:
I just made pumpkin pancakes the other night using a different recipe.  I thought they were o.k. but really thick (I could hardly swallow without drinking some milk!).  Anyway, in hunting a new recipe I found this one and was astonished at the difference in taste and texture.  These are amazing!  I omitted the baking powder and instead added 1 cup of yogurt, 1 cup less of milk, and 1 extra teaspoon of baking soda.  I also added a little extra milk as suggested.  It took about 5 minutes to cook each pan full but it was worth it!  Definately try these!
